Private individuals can help by 1. sending a letter to the FCC to voice your support for net neutrality (the deadline for comments is coming up fast!) and 2. spreading the message on social media. The people fought back PIPA and SOPA before and weâ€™re ready to stand up again!

Title: TV News Record: Fox on CNN, getting Gorsuch right + fact-checks
Article: We changed our name! Our weekly updates from the TV News Archive are now titled TV News Record, to reflect our goal of providing many ways for viewers to put the news in context, whether through fact checks from our national fact-checking partners, visualizations of patterns of news coverage, or other ways of using TV news metadata to deepen analysis of the news. This week we present fact-checks by fact-checking groups of claims about gang arrests, fraudulent votes, the Russia investigations, and Medicaid. But first, some observations about cable news coverage of news this week and realized hopes for the newest Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch by the religious right.  Fox devotes most air time to CNN story retractionÂ  In a stark reminder of how whichÂ cable channel you watch affects what news you see, Dave Weigel ofÂ The Washington PostÂ noted this week that while health care was big news on Capitol Hill Tuesday evening, Fox cable stations were busy reporting on the falloutÂ over a retracted story by CNN related to Russia investigations: â€œThe networkâ€™s prime-time shows, ratings kings of cable news, ignored the health-care story,â€ he wrote. Meanwhile, â€œThe CNN story, sparked by a retracted report on Russia and Trump and inflamed by the sting video, sprawled across multiple segments.â€ Weigelâ€™s analysis is borne out by plugging key search terms into the Television Explorer, a tool built by data scientist Kalev Leetaru fueled by TV News Archive data. Search for the termÂ â€œretractionâ€ near â€œstoryâ€ over the 72-hour period ending on June 30,Â and Fox news dominates. A search for â€œretractionâ€ near â€œstoryâ€ over 72 hour period ending at 10:20 am ET, June 30, 2017. The converse is also true: a similar search for â€œhealth careâ€ near â€œSenateâ€ yielded the following results, with CNN Â devoting the most attention to the story, andÂ more than four times as much as Fox News did. â€œHealth careâ€ near â€œSenate,â€ 72 hour period ending 10:20 am ET, June 30 2017. Such searches are easily done on Television Explorer. With the explosion of coverage over the past 24 hours about President Donald Trumpâ€™s tweets about MSNBC â€œMorning Joeâ€ co-hosts Mika Brzezinski and Joe Scarborough, weâ€™re keeping on eye on this search of â€œTrumpâ€ near â€œtweet.â€ Questions? Contact tvnews@archive.org.  Getting Gorsuch right In the lead up to the Senateâ€™s confirmationÂ of Neil Gorsuch as the newest member of the U.S. Supreme Court earlier this year, many commentators noted that his appeal to conservatives was enhanced by his stanceÂ on religious issues. With the conclusion of the Courtâ€™s term on Monday, Gorsuchâ€™s champions were vindicated with his decisions in such matters asÂ Trinity Lutheran Church of Columbia, Inc. v. Comer, in which Gorsuch sided with the majority affirming that a church was eligible for public funding to build a playground. Here is CNN reporter Ariane de Vogue back in April 2017 explaining why the case matters:  And now on to this weekâ€™s highlighted TV news fact-checks. Claim: MS-13 gang members are being deported by the thousands (hundreds) At a rally speech in Iowa on June 21, President Trump said of MS-13, â€œThey donâ€™t like to shoot people. They like to cut people. They do things that nobody can believe. These are true animals. We are moving them out of the country by the thousands, by the thousands. Weâ€™re getting them out, MS-13.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee reported for the Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker that while the Trump administration has increased enforcement against gang activity, deportations â€œare in the hundreds, not the thousands, under Trump.â€ Â The reporters at FactCheck.org concurred, and quotedÂ Danielle Bennett, a spokesperson for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, who said the agency â€œdoes not track gang removals by specific gang.â€  Claim: People hired for independent Russia investigations are all Hillary supporters (mostly false) In a recent TV interview, President Trump said â€œI can say that the people that have been hired (for the independent Russia investigation) are all Hillary Clinton supporters, some of them worked for Hillary Clinton.â€ For PolitiFact, Manuela Tobias reported â€œThree of the eight available Mueller hires made campaign contributions to Clinton, which undermines Trumpâ€™s statement that all are Clinton supporters. Furthermore, none of them have worked for Clinton directly. Two represented either the Clinton Foundation or an aide, never her, and working for WilmerHale, which has also represented key members of Trumpâ€™s White House.â€  Youâ€™re grandfathered in if you became a Medicaid recipient under Obamacare (mostly false) White House adviser Kellyanne Conway said on Sunday about the proposed GOP health care legislation, â€œIf you became a Medicaid recipient through the Obamacare expansion, you are grandfathered in.â€ Joshua Gillin reportedÂ forÂ PolitiFact, â€œThe â€˜grandfathered expansion enrolleesâ€™ would have to maintain near-continuous coverage, with no breaks of more than a month, in order to get the higher rate.â€Â He continued, â€œContinuous coverage can be hard for Medicaid recipients to maintain. Medicaid patients have to continuously provide proof of income, and if a patient goes over the income limit, they lose coverage. This is a concept known as churning.â€  Claim: 5.7 million undocumented immigrants might have voted in 2008 (wrong) On a recent morning show, Fox co-host Ainsley Earhardt said of the 2008 election, â€œ5.7 million â€“Â thatâ€™s how many illegal immigrants might have voted.â€ According to Amy Sherman at PolitiFact, â€œTrump has made repeated claims about massive voter fraud and election rigging, which weâ€™ve debunked again and again and again and again and again and again and again (and we debunked a claim by his spokesman Sean Spicer).â€ She goes on to explain that the figure used by Earhardt â€œis based on an extrapolation of a controversial study that relied on a very small number of responses. Researchers involved in the underlying survey of voters have cautioned against using their data to reach conclusions about noncitizen voters.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: Knight Prototype Fund winners use TV News Archive to fight misinformation
Article: We are delighted to report that two ofÂ Â 20 winnersÂ recently announced Knight Prototype Fundâ€™s $1 million challenge to combatÂ misinformation will directly draw on theÂ TV News Archive. One of these is the Bad Idea Factoryâ€™s â€œGlorious ContextuBot.â€ Letâ€™s sayÂ you come across a tweet that is brandishing a TV news clip to bolster a strong statement on a controversial issue â€“ but you have no idea where or when or whether that clip was aired, by whom, and whether or not itâ€™s legitimate. The ContextuBot will take the Duplitron 5000, an audio fingerprinting tool developed to track political ads for the Political TV Ad Archive, and build uponÂ it to help users find any relevant TV news coverage of thatÂ video snippet. If the video was aired, users will be able to see what came before and after the report. The team, led by the Dan Schultz, senior creative technologist of the TV News Archive, will bring in veteran media innovators Mark Boas and Laurian Gridnoc of Hyperaudio and Trint. Together they will not only build the ContextuBot, but will also work to improve the speed and accuracy of the Duplitron. From sticky notes to Glorious Contextubot: on right, Dan Schultz, TV News Archive senior creative technologist, plots prototype plans Second,Â Joostwareâ€˜s â€œWho Said Whatâ€ project will use deep learning algorithms to annotate TV news clips to identify speakers and what they are talking about. Developing this capability will help fact checkers sort through and identify claims by public officials, pundits, and others that bear examination. We are delighted to work with Joostware as part of our ongoing goal to collaborate with researchers, companies, and others who are exploring how to use Artificial Intelligence tools to draw onÂ the Internet Archiveâ€™s collections toÂ enhance journalism and research. The KnightÂ Prototype Fund will award $50,000 apiece to each of the 20 winners, who are now charged with developing their ideas over the next nine months.Â The John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, the Democracy Fund, and the Rita Allen Foundation all support the effort. Winners attended a human-centered design training workshop last week in Phoenix, Arizona, as part of the support offered by the foundations.

Title: TV news fact-checked: health care & more + this press briefing will not be televised
Article: by Katie Dahl and Nancy Watzman This week the Senate releasedÂ its version of health care, so to mark the occasion weÂ offer a trio of recent health care fact checks fromÂ The Washington Postâ€˜s Fact Checker. Other fact-checking highlights include: a claim that Saudia Arabia has been spending money on Trump hotels (true, says PolitiFact) and Ivanka Trump asserts American workers have a skill gap (also true, reportsÂ Politifact). But before we present these fact-checks, we pause for a moment to presentÂ this commentary from CNNâ€™s Jim Acosta on the White Houseâ€™s refusal to allow cameras in a growing number ofÂ press briefings: â€œThat wouldnâ€™t be tolerated in city council meetings, or at a governorâ€™s press conference,â€ he noted. â€œAnd here we have the representative of the president of the United States saying no you canâ€™t cover it that wayâ€¦.itâ€™s like weâ€™re not even covering a White House anymoreâ€¦itâ€™s like weâ€™re just covering bad reality television, is what it feels like now.â€  Claim: 1.8 million jobs will be lost as a result of the AHCA (two Pinocchios) Earlier this month, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D., Calif., said, â€œAmericans will lose their health coverage because of his proposal. And it is a job loser. Estimated to be 1.8 million jobs lost. Donald Trump is a job loser.â€ Glenn Kessler reported for the Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker: â€œWe often warn readers to be wary of job claims made by politicians based on think-tank studies. This is a case in point. Pelosi was careful to say â€˜estimated,â€™ but two groups of researchers, using apparently the same economic model, came up with different estimates of jobs losses under the AHCA by 2022 â€“ 1.8 million and 413,000.â€  Claim: the reconciliation process will be used for the AHCA (upside down Pinocchio or flip-flop) At a recent press briefing, Sen. Mitch McConnell, R., Ky., described the upcoming legislative process for the American Health Care Act, â€œUnfortunately, it will have to be a Republicans-only exercise. But weâ€™re working hard to get there.â€ Kessler responded that â€œMcConnellâ€™s position has changed, even though he will not acknowledge it. He was against the reconciliation process for health care in 2010; he has embraced it now. He was against secrecy and closed-door dealmaking before; he now oversees the most secretive health-care bill process ever. And he was against voting on a bill that was broadly unpopular â€” and now he is pushing for a bill even more unpopular than the ACA in 2010.â€  Claim: insurers are leaving the health care exchanges because of Obamacare (three Pinocchios) President Donald Trump talked with Republican senators about health care, saying among other claims, â€œInsurers are fleeing the market. Last week it was announced that one of the largest insurers is pulling out of Ohio â€” the great state of Ohio.â€  Â Kessler wrote that Trump â€œignores that many say they are exiting the business because of uncertainty created by the Trump administration, in particular whether it will continue to pay â€˜cost-sharing reductionsâ€™ to insurance companies. These payments help reduce co-pays and deductibles for low-income patients on the exchanges. Without those subsidies, insurance companies have to foot more of the bill.â€Â   Claim: Saudi Arabia is spending big on Trump Hotels (mostly true) The attorney general for the District of Columbia, Karl Racine, said at a recent press conference that â€œThe Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, whose government has important business and policy before the president of the United States, has already spent hundreds of thousands of dollars at the Trump International Hotel.â€  Smitha Rajan reported for PolitiFact, â€œThe Foreign Agent Registration Act report mentions at least one filing which clearly shows that the Saudi government spent $270,000 at the Trump International Hotel for lodging and boarding expenses between October 2016 and March 2017. Itâ€™s not clear whether the entire expenses were paid before or after Trump became president. Our research showed it was some of Â both.â€  Claim: there are 6 million job openings but workers donâ€™t have the skills needed (true) During a recent interview on Fox & Friends, Ivanka Trump, assistant to the president and daughter of the president, said â€œThere are 6 million available American jobs, so weâ€™re constantly hearing from CEOâ€™s that they have job openings, but they donâ€™t have workers with the skill set they need to fill those jobs.â€ For PolitiFact, Louis Jacobson rated her claim â€œtrue,â€ reporting â€œThe number she cites is correct, and sheâ€™s right to say that the skills gap plays a role. Economists warn against overestimating the role played by the skills gap in all 6 million job openings, both because other factors play a role (such as the image gap) and because the skills barriers posed are often more modest than having to earn an academic degree or to obtain specialized training.â€

Title: Connect with Internet Archive at ALA 2017â€”Chicago
Article: Come meet Internet Archive Founder, Brewster Kahle and Director of Partnerships, Wendy Hanamura at ALA Annual 2017 in Chicago. Saturday, June 24 10:30-11:30 a.m. Â Making your library a digital library by 2020  Where: Â McCormick Place W194b Who: Â   Â Â Brewster Kahle, Founder & Digital Librarian andÂ Wendy Hanamura, Director of Partnerships  Description: Â Come hear the Internet Archive teamÂ discuss OpenLibrariesâ€”a project that will enableÂ every US library to become a more digital library. Working with library partners and organizations serving the print disabled, the Internet Archive proposes bringing 4 million books online, through purchase or digitization, starting with the century of books missing from our digital shelves. Our plan includes at-scale circulation of these e-books, enabling libraries owning the physical works to lend digital copies to their patrons. This will enable thousands of libraries to unlock their analog collections for a new generation of learners,Â enabling free, long-term, public access to knowledge. Semifinalist in MacArthur Foundationâ€™s 100&Change: Â This Internet Archive project has been selected as one of the eight semifinalists in the 100&Change MacArthur Foundation Challenge which will provide $100 million over five years to an organization trying to solve one of the worldâ€™s toughest problems. Â In our case: providing free access to the best knowledge available. Brewster and WendyÂ will describe the current state of project planning and listen to your feedback to ensure this project has transformative impact on the communities you serve. Monday, June 26 1:30-2:15 Â Conversation Starter: Â The Library of 2020 â€“ Building A Collaborative Digital Collection of 4 Million Books  Where: Â McCormick Place W183a Who: Â   Â Â Wendy Hanamura, Dir. of PartnershipsÂ & Brewster Kahle, Digital Librarian  Description: Â Even in this digital age, millions of books are not accessible to online learners and the print disabled. We in the library community havenâ€™t been able toÂ keep up withÂ this digital demand, stymied by costs, eBook restrictions, and missing infrastructure.Â By making millions of books digitally available, weÂ can unlock them for communities with severely limited or no access to those books. Because of distance, cost, time-constraints, or disability, people in many communities are too often unable to accessÂ physical books. Digital content is instantly available to people at a distance, at allÂ hours, and with widely ranging physical abilities.Â Together with library and accessibility partners, the Internet Archive proposes bringing 4 million books online, through purchase or digitization. Our plan includes at-scale circulation of these eBooks, enabling libraries owning the physical works to lend digital copies. As 1 of 8 semifinalists for MacArthurâ€™s 100&Change award, we seek your feedback. The goal: bringing libraries and learners 4 million eBooks, enabling the free, long-term, public access to knowledge. NOTE: Â To be live streamed via Facebook Live at https://www.facebook.com/internetnetarchive/ All times are in Central Daylight Time. For full schedule, visit https://www.eventscribe.com/2017/ALA-Annual/.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Donald and Ivanka Trump
Article: By Katie Dahl Our fact-checking partners spent time on the Trumps this week, covering Ivanka Trumpâ€™s claim about women in STEM occupations and the Presidentâ€™s claims about James Comey and Michael Flynn, record-setting nominations delays, how long it actually took to build the Hoover Dam and the Golden Gate Bridge, and his involvement in a new coal mine opening. Claim: Trump said â€œlet this goâ€ referencing the FBI investigation of Michael Flynn (contradicted by Trump) In his written testimony submitted to the Senate Intelligence Committee on June 7, former FBI director James Comey wrote that President Trump said, â€œI hope you can see your way clear to letting this go, to letting Flynn go. He is a good guy. I hope you can let this go.â€ In a PolitiFact article reporting on conflicting claims between Comey and the White House, Lauren Carroll wrote that when asked about this allegation in a May 18 press conference, the President said, â€œNo. No. Next question.â€  Claim: Trump nominees faced â€˜record-setting longâ€™ delays (true)  In a comment at a cabinet meeting on June 12, President Trump said, â€œThis is our first Cabinet meeting with the entire Cabinet present. The confirmation process has been record-setting long â€” and I mean record-setting long â€” with some of the finest people in our country being delayed and delayed and delayed.â€ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker Glenn Kessler reported that Trump â€œfaced unusually sustained opposition for a new president, including cloture votes demanded for 14 of his choices,â€ and gave the President their â€œGeppetto Checkmarkâ€ for correct statements.  Claim: women make up 47% of workforce and just 23% of STEM occupations (mostly true) In an interview this week, Ivanka Trump said, â€œWomenâ€¦ represent 47 percent of the overall work force, we only make up 23 percent of STEM-related [science, technology, engineering, and mathematics] occupations.â€ That is â€œnot far off the mark,â€ according to PolitiFactâ€™s Louis Jacobson. He went on to report, â€œTrump was correct about the percentage of the overall workforce that is female,â€ and â€œThe report [2016 National Science Board and the National Science Foundation] found that in 2013, women represented 29 percent of individuals in science and engineering occupations. Thatâ€™s higher than Trumpâ€™s 23 percent, although it supports her broader point â€” that women are underrepresented in STEM fields.â€  Claim: Americans â€˜built the Golden Gate Bridge in four years and the Hoover Dam in fiveâ€™ (misleading) In his weekly address on June 9, President Trump said, â€œwe are the nation that built the Golden Gate Bridge in four years and the Hoover Dam in five. Now, it takes as much as a decade just to plan a major permit or a major infrastructure or anything even remotely major in our country, and thatâ€™s ridiculous and itâ€™s going to change.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee gave Trump â€œthree Pinocchiosâ€ for this claim. She reported for the Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, â€œTrump describes the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge and Hoover Dam as projects that were constructed over four or five years, unbound by the years of permitting and regulatory restrictions that current-day projects face. But Trump only focuses on the literal construction of the projects, and overlooks the many years of bureaucratic negotiating and regulating that took place leading up to the construction.â€  Claim: Trump is putting miners back to work with the opening of a new coal mine (hard to believe) In a speech in Cincinnati, Ohio on June 7, President Trump said, â€œNext week weâ€™re opening a big coal mine. You know about that. One in Pennsylvania. Itâ€™s actually a new mine. That hadnâ€™t happened in a long time, folks. But weâ€™re putting the people and weâ€™re putting the miners back to work.â€ â€œTrump did not name the Pennsylvania mine,â€ reported Robert Farley for FactCheck.org, â€œand the White House did not respond to us. But these kinds of events are rare enough that it is clear he is referring to the June 8 grand opening of the Corsa Coal Companyâ€™s Acosta Deep Mine more than 60 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. What did Trumpâ€™s presidency have to do with its opening? Nothing. Development of the Acosta mine began in September, two months before the presidential election.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: AMA about OpenLibrariesâ€“our proposal for MacArthurâ€™s 100&Change
Article: Live Chat on YouTube Live, Thursday, June 15 from 10-11:30 a.m. PT with Brewster Kahle, Founder and Digital Librarian Wendy Hanamura, Director of Partnerships John Gonzalez, Director of Engineering What would it mean if you had easy online access to 4 millionÂ modern booksâ€“the equivalent of a great public or university library? Â What would that meanÂ for the print disabled and those unable to reach their public libraries? How wouldÂ that change innovationÂ and scholarship? In an era of misinformation, how can we tieÂ informationÂ toÂ the published works of humankind? Those are some of the questions weâ€™ve been asking ourselves at the Internet Archive as we honeÂ our plans for Open Librariesâ€“our proposal to the MacArthur Foundationâ€™s 100&Change competition to tackleÂ one of the worldâ€™s toughest problems. We are now one of eight semifinalists vying for $100 million grant to carry out our goal: democratizing access to knowledge by providing free, long-term access to a digital library of 4 million modern books.Â We call our project Open Libraries because we wantÂ to help every library in the nationÂ to provide itsÂ members with digital access to its rich collections. The Internet Archive, working with library and accessibility partners, has a plan to bringÂ 4 million books online, through purchase or digitization, starting with the 20th century books missing from our digital shelves. Our plan includes at-scale circulation of these e-books, enabling libraries owning the physical works to lend digital copies to their patrons. Working with our accessibility partners, we will also make this collection availableÂ to the print disabled around the world. Â And our team of curators will help make sure we create an inclusive, diverse collection of 20th century texts. We now have the technology and legal frameworks to transform our library system by 2023 to provide more democratic access to knowledgeâ€“for library patrons, scholars, students and the print disabled. We want to hear what you think. Â Help us hone our plans, test our hypotheses, and dream big! Ask us a question or post an idea in the comments below. We will answer them during our YouTube Live. Â Or tweet us usingÂ #OpenLibrariesAMA.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Trump, Pruitt, Gore, and Handel
Article: By Katie Dahl In this weekâ€™s roundup of fact-checked TV news, the term â€œtravel banâ€ gets a final word from the president, new coal mining jobs numbers are questioned, Gore and Pruitt give competing claims about Paris Agreement target requirements, Trump supporters are polled for their approval of the Paris Agreement, two elements of the Iran Deal are clarified, and one of Trumpâ€™s arguments for privatizing the FAA gets a context check. Claim: executive order is a â€œtravel banâ€ (the president says it is) In a tweet on June 5, President Donald Trump wrote: â€œPeople, the lawyers and the courts can call it whatever they want, but I am calling it what we need and what it is, a TRAVEL BAN!â€ According to Miriam Valverde at PolitiFact, this statement ran counter to what â€œhis spokesman, administration officials, lawyers, courts and others call it.â€ Among many examples collected by Valverde are three instances (1, 2, 3) of Secretary of Homeland Security John Kelly calling it a â€œtravel pauseâ€ and twice saying the executive order â€œis not a travel ban.â€ The most recent interview was May 28. PolitiFactâ€™s conclusion: â€œItâ€™s a travel ban.â€  Claim: weâ€™ve added 50,000 coal mining jobs since last quarter, 7,000 since May (misleading spin) In three TV interviews (1, 2, 3) with major networks on Sunday, June 4, Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt made this claim: â€œWeâ€™ve had over 50,000 jobs since last quarter, coal jobs, mining jobs, created in this country. We had almost 7,000 mining and coal jobs created in the month of May alone.â€ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, Glenn Kessler, gave Pruitt a â€œfour Pinocchioâ€ rating for this claim, writing â€œthe biggest problem with Pruittâ€™s statistic is that most of the gain in â€˜miningâ€™ jobs has nothing to do with coal. Most of the new jobs were in a subcategory called â€˜support activities for mining,â€™ which accounted for more than 40,000 of the new jobs since October and more than 30,000 of the jobs since January.â€ For FactCheck.org, Eugene Kiely reported the same information and further that â€œBLS [Bureau of Labor Statistics] could not tell us how many of those jobs were related to coal mining, as opposed to gas, oil, metal ores and nonmetallic minerals. We do know, however, that most of those jobs support the gas and oil industries.â€  Claim: US could change emissions targets under Paris Agreement without pulling out of it (Gore was right) In dueling Sunday political talk show interviews, former Vice President Al Gore said of the Paris Agreement, â€œthe requirements were voluntary. He [Trump] could have changed the requirements,â€ while EPA Administrator Pruitt, on another show, said â€œNo, no, no. No, not under the agreement. Not under the agreementâ€¦ Youâ€™re wrongâ€ to Jake Tapper of CNNâ€™s statement: â€œYou can change those targets.â€ Pruitt went on to claim that the targets â€œcan only be ratcheted up.â€ For their SciCheck project, FactCheck.orgâ€™s Vanessa Schipani reported, â€œThe Paris Agreement is voluntary. Countries arenâ€™t penalized for failing to adhere to their proposed emissions cuts. So President Donald Trump could have ignored or changed the U.S. pledged emissions targets without withdrawing from the agreement.â€         Claim: most Trump supporters wanted the US to stay in the Paris Agreement (mostly false) In another interview on Sunday, Gore said, â€œA majority of President Trumpâ€™s supporters and voters wanted to stay inâ€ the Paris Agreement. For PolitiFact, John Kruzel reported that on â€œGoreâ€™s central point, the poll [Yale-George Mason poll] found that among Trump voters, 47 percent wanted to participate in the Paris Agreement, compared to 28 percent who supported opting out, with a quarter expressing no opinion. So, 47 percent support among Trump voters amounts to a plurality â€” not a majority, as Gore said.â€  Claim: US flew $2 billion to Iran and Obama administration said it was used for terrorism (half true) In a debate between Jon Ossoff and Karen Handel leading up to a special election for Georgiaâ€™s sixth congressional district later this month â€” the election resulted from Tom Price being tapped by the Trump administration to lead the Department of Health and Human Services â€” Handel made this claim. â€œNearly $2 billion in cash was flown over to Iran, money that the Obama administration has admitted is being used for terrorists and to support further activities there.â€ According to Jon Greenberg of PolitiFact, â€œThe Iran deal focused on reducing Iranâ€™s stockpiles of nuclear-grade material, but a key provision unlocked Iranian assets that had been frozen for decades. How much money was there is a matter of debate.â€ He went on to report that John Kerry, then Secretary of State in the Obama administration, appeared on TV and said â€œâ€˜I think that some of it will end up in the hands of the IRGC (Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps) or of other entities, some of which are labeled terrorists,â€™ Kerry said. â€˜To some degree, Iâ€™m not going to sit here and tell you that every component of that can be prevented.'â€  Claim: the Obama administration spent over $7 billion on the aviation system and failed (two Pinocchios) In comments announcing a plan to privatize part of the federal air traffic control apparatus, President Trump said â€œthe previous administration spent over $7 billion trying to upgrade the system and totally failed. Honestly, they didnâ€™t know what the hell they were doing.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee reported for the Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker that â€œTrump characterizes this program as an Obama-era error, but the planning for the massive overhaul began in 2000. Congress authorized the FAA to tackle these changes in 2003, and the Department of Transportation launched the NextGen program in January 2004â€¦ There have been delays and changes in the project, but high-priority projects have made progress.â€ She gave this claim â€œtwo Pinocchios.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: Help Us Defend Net Neutrality!
Article: Please stand with the Internet Archive and over 50 alliesÂ in the effort to protect free speech by adding your name in support of net neutrality and writing to your Congressperson today. We have only 40 days left to stopÂ a current FCC proposal that couldÂ upend the governmentâ€™sÂ prior commitment to net neutrality and seriously threaten free speech online. If you represent an organization, please consider participating in the movement on July 12 to inform the public on how to take action.  The end of net neutrality could be devastating to the Internet community at large in a multitude of ways. For example, relatively small organizations like the ArchiveÂ donâ€™t have the resources to negotiate special deals with ISPs, let alone pay new tolls in order to reach users who rely on our service to broadcast their voice. Many like usÂ could be relegated to anÂ Internet â€œslow laneâ€ whileÂ bigger sites and closer partners of ISPs enjoyÂ faster speeds. We have fought against threats to a freeÂ and open Internet beforeÂ and won.Â On September 10, 2014, weÂ came together asÂ hundreds of organizations and over 4 million peopleÂ to support net neutralityÂ and speak outÂ against SOPA. In 2015, the FCCÂ heardÂ our voicesÂ and issuedÂ a landmarkÂ rulingÂ called the â€œOpen Internet Orderâ€Â that declared the Internet a neutral public utility which couldnâ€™t be censored or manipulated by corporate interests. Fast forward to 2017. Only 18 months after the FCC reached a decision to protect our free speech, they have switched stances and are doing everything in their power to pass Docket 17-108, which would reverse the 2015 decision we worked so hard to achieve. The effort is led by a commissioner who was formerly a lawyer for one of the ISPs thatÂ has lobbied hardest against net neutrality and stands to directly benefit from this policy reversal. At our expense. We need your help. Protect digital free speech and universal access to all knowledge.Â Please make your voice heard:Â send comments toÂ the FCC, contact your Congressperson, and connect your organization with the July 12 campaign, and share these links with your friends.

Title: MIT Press Classics Available Soon at Archive.org
Article: For more than eighty years, MIT Press has been publishing acclaimed titles in science, technology, art and architecture. Â Now, thanks to a new partnership between the Internet ArchiveÂ and MIT Press, readers will be able to borrow these classics online for the first time. With generous support from Arcadia, a charitable fund of Peter Baldwin and Lisbet Rausing,Â thisÂ partnership represents an important advance in providingÂ free, long-term public access to knowledge. â€œThese books represent some of the finest scholarship ever produced, but right now they are very hard to find,â€ said Brewster Kahle, founder and Digital Librarian of the Internet Archive. â€œTogether with MIT Press, we will enable the patrons of every library that owns one of these books to borrow it onlineâ€“one copy at a time.â€ This joint initiative is a crucial early step in Internet Archiveâ€™s ambitious plans to digitize, preserve and provide public access to four million books, by partnering widely with university presses and other publishers, authors, and libraries. Â The Internet ArchiveÂ is one of eight groups named semi-finalists in 100&Change, a global competition for a single $100 million grant from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. The competition seeks bold solutions to critical problems of our time. MIT Pressâ€™ Kelly McDougall (l) and Editor, Amy Brand, holding one of the publisherâ€™s classic books. MIT Press Director, Amy Brand said, â€œOne of my top ambitions for the MIT Press has been to ensure that our entire legacy of publications is digitized, accessible, searchable, discoverable now and in perpetuity. Partnering with Internet Archive to achieve this objective is a dream come true not only for me and my colleagues at the Press, but also for many of our authors whose earlier works are completely unavailable or not easily accessible.â€ Â  â€œLending online permits libraries to fulfill their mission in the digital age, allowing anyone Â to borrow through the ether copies of works they own,â€ said Professor Peter Baldwin, co-founder of Arcadia. Â â€œThe IA-MIT collaboration is a big step in the direction of realizing a universal library, accessible to anyone, anywhere.â€ One of the hundreds of titles coming soon to archive.org We will be scanning an initial group of 1,500 MIT Press titles at Internet Archiveâ€™s Boston Public Library facility, including Cyril Stanley Smithâ€™s 1980 book, From Art to Science: Seventy-Two Objects Illustrating the Nature of Discovery, and Frederick Law OlmstedÂ and Theodora Kimballâ€™s Forty Years of Landscape Architecture: Central Park, which was published in 1973. The oldest title in the group is Arthur C. Hardyâ€™s 1936 Handbook of Colorimetry. John Palfrey, Head of School at Phillips Academy Andover and well-known public access advocate, described the partnership as â€œa truly ground-breaking development in open scholarship that I hope will inspire other university presses to follow suit, since so many excellent and important books are effectively out of circulation by virtue of being analog-only in a digital world.â€ The Internet Archive has already begun digitizing MIT Pressâ€™ backlist and they will be available at archive.org soon. The set of 1500 deep backlist works should be available by the end of 2017.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Gianforte, Gingrich, Pelosi & more
Article: By Nancy Watzman and Katie Dahl In this weekâ€™s round-up from the TV News Archive, Â our fact-checking partners declare that Greg Gianforte, now Montanaâ€™s U.S. House representative-elect, was the aggressor in a conflict with aÂ reporter; Newt Gingrich spread a conspiracy theory; House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stretched claims about how veterans could be hurt under the House GOP health care bill; and White House budget director Mick Mulvaney double-counted money. Claim: Guardian reporterâ€™s aggression, not Gianforteâ€™s, caused altercation (flip that) On May 24 aÂ campaign spokesperson for Greg Gianforte, who has since won the Montana U.S. House race, said, â€œTonight, as Greg was giving a separate interview in a private office, The Guardianâ€˜s Ben Jacobs entered the office without permission, aggressively shoved a recorder in Gregâ€™s face, and began asking badgering questions. Jacobs was asked to leave. After asking Jacobs to lower the recorder, Jacobs declined. Greg then attempted to grab the phone that was pushed in his face. Jacobs grabbed Gregâ€™s wrist, and spun away from Greg, pushing them both to the ground. Itâ€™s unfortunate that this aggressive behavior from a liberal journalist created this scene at our campaign volunteer BBQ.â€ As reported by John Kruzel and Smitha Rajan for PolitiFact, a Fox News reporter was in the room at the time and gave this account. â€œâ€¦Gianforte grabbed Jacobs by the neck with both hands and slammed him into the ground behind him. Faith, Keith and I watched in disbelief as Gianforte then began punching the reporter.â€ Gianforte has since apologized.  Claim: DNC staffer assassinated after giving emails to WikiLeaks (unsupported) Newt Gingrich, a former Republican House Speaker, said in a TV interview, â€œwe have this very strange story now of this young man who worked for the Democratic National Committee, who apparently was assassinated at 4 in the morning, having given WikiLeaks something like 23,000. Iâ€™m sorry, 53,000 emails and 17,000 attachments.â€ â€œGingrich Spreads Conspiracy Theory,â€ read a headline from FactCheck.org. Eugene Kiely reported â€œthereâ€™s no evidence for his claim.â€ PunditFact, a project of PolitiFact, gave Gingrich itsÂ worst fact-check rating, Pants on Fire. Â Lauren Carroll reported, â€œHours after Fox published its report, (Rod) Wheeler recanted. He told CNN that he hadnâ€™t seen the evidence himself, and his knowledge of Richâ€™s alleged email contact with WikiLeaks came from the national Fox News reporter, not his own investigative work.â€ (Note: Kiely also made use of the Wayback Machine in his piece, linking to a now-deleted Fox News story now saved at the Internet Archive. Washington PostÂ reportersÂ Kristine Phillips and Peter HolleyÂ published similar links in their story on how Fox News retracted its story on Seth Rich.)  Claim: seven million veterans will lose tax credit for their families in health care bill (three Pinocchios) During a speech at a conference hosted by the Center for American Progress, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D., Calif., said of the House-passedÂ GOP health care reform bill, â€œSeven million veterans will lose their tax credit for their families in this bill.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee reported for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker that â€œveterans â€˜couldâ€™ â€” not â€˜will,â€™ as Pelosi says â€” lose tax credits if the current protections donâ€™t carry over under a new health lawâ€¦ Would it affect 7 million veterans and their families? Not necessarily.â€  Claim: economic growth will pay for both eliminating the deficit and tax cuts (wait a minute) In a press conference about President Trumpâ€™s proposed 2018 fiscal budget, White House budget director Mick Mulvaney said â€œwe get to an actual balance on this budget within the 10-year window,â€ because â€œwe will bring back 3% economic growth to this country and those numbers are assumed in this budget. By the way if we donâ€™t the budget will never balance. You will never see a balanced budget again. We refuse to accept that the new normal in this country. Three percent was the old normal. Three percent will be the new normal again under the Trump administration and that is part and parcel with the foundation of this budget.â€ Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin also claimed economic growth would pay for the proposed revenue-neutral tax plan, â€œThis will pay for itself with growth and with reduced â€” reduction of different deductions and closing loopholes.â€ â€œWait a minute, say tax and budget experts, thatâ€™s double-counting the same money,â€ reported Robert Farley of FactCheck.org. Roberton Williams of the Tax Policy Center told FactCheck.org that you canâ€™t assume growth will balance the budget and offset tax cuts, â€œBoth of those are not plausible,â€ he said  Claim: Manafort and others visited Moscow during the campaign (mostly false) In a TV interview, Rep. Maxine Waters, D., Calif., said â€œI really do believe that much of what you saw coming out of Trumpâ€™s mouth was a play from Putinâ€™s playbookâ€¦ I think you can see visits, you know, to Moscow made during the campaign by (Paul) Manafort and others.â€ â€œFrom whatâ€™s on the public record, Manafort didnâ€™t go at all, and (Carter) Page went onceâ€¦ Waters made it sound like this was a regular occurrence. We rate this claim Mostly False.â€ Jon Greenberg reported for PolitiFact.  Claim: Wisconsin high-risk pool had 8 or 9 plans, people could go to any doctor, and premiums and copays were cheaper than Obamacare (half true) In response to criticism from Democrats for the House-passed health care proposal, Rep. Paul Ryan, R., Wis., said â€œIn Wisconsin, we had a really successful high-risk pool. Ten percent of the people in the individual market in Wisconsin were in the state high-risk pool. They had eight or nine plans to choose from. They could go to any doctor or any hospital they wanted. And their premiums and copays were cheaper than they are under Obamacare today.â€ For PolitiFact, Tom Kertscher reported â€œHeâ€™s essentially on target on the first two parts, but not on the thirdâ€¦ it canâ€™t be flatly stated that the high-risk pool plans were cheaper than Obamacare plans for comparable coverage.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribeÂ here.

Title: Re: User account breach
Article: The FBI helpfully told us that they found a copy of the Archiveâ€™s user database, dated prior to 2012, during one of their investigations. This database did not have much information that is not on the website, but it had lightly encrypted passwords of the users at the time. We have since upped the encryption level. We have not noticed any uptick in compromised account activity at the Archive, so weâ€™d bet against past malicious use. We will be emailing all Archive patrons who held accounts prior to 2012, containing much of the same information you see here. We are sorry for this inconvenience.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Comey, Schumer, McMaster, Mueller
Article: It was a yet another extraordinary week in U.S. politics, with a series of explosive news reports centeringÂ on President Donald Trump. The TV News Archive is saving history as it happens, as well as linking relevant fact-checks by FactCheck.org, PolitiFact, and The Washington Postâ€˜s Fact Checker to statements by public officials. On Sunday shows, Schumer demands release of tapesâ€“if they exist Senate Majority Leader Charles â€œChuckâ€Â Schumer, D., N.Y., made the rounds of Sunday news talk shows, appearing on â€œMeet the Pressâ€ and â€œState of the Union,â€ calling for a special prosecutor to investigate possible connections between the Trump campaign andÂ Russia among other matters. In this clip, Schumer says Trump should turn over tapesâ€“theÂ possibility of which were raised by Trump in a tweet on May 12â€“if they exist, of the presidentâ€™s conversations with now former FBI director James Comey. In this piece titled â€œTrump vs. Comey,â€Â FactCheck.org reporters Eugene Kiely and Robert Farley trace the history of statements by the president and Comey about their discussions. They note, â€œWhite House Press Secretary Sean Spicer has repeatedly refused to answer whether Trump has such recordings. In his interview with Jeanine Pirro, Trump said, â€œWell, that I canâ€™t talk about. I wonâ€™t talk about that.â€  McMaster reacts to report that Trump shared intelligence with Russians AfterÂ The Washington Post reported, on May 15, that Trump had revealed â€œhighly classified informationâ€ to Russian envoys visiting the White House last week, national security adviser H.R. McMaster defended the presidentÂ that day and at a press conferenceÂ the following day. Among his assertions: â€œThe story that came out tonight as reported is false.â€  â€œThe key phrase is â€œas reported,â€ wrote Glenn Kessler, for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, in a piece that dissects McMasterâ€™s statements before the press.Â â€œWith this language, McMaster in theory could dispute anyÂ element, no matter how small, as false. He notably did not say the story was false.â€ John Kruzel, writing for PolitiFact,Â tracedÂ the â€œshiftingâ€ explanations from the White House on what happened at the meeting with the Russians, including McMasterâ€™s statements. Former FBI director Robert Mueller appointed special counsel Wednesday, May 17 brought the news that the U.S. Department of Justice appointed Robert Mueller as a special counsel to investigate possible connections between Trumpâ€™s 2016 campaign and Russia. Here PolitiFact reporter Lauren Carroll gives the basics on Muellerâ€™s background and experience. The TV News Archive contains numerous historical clips of Mueller, who served as FBI director under Â Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama, including this brief farewell interviewÂ he gave to ABC in 2013, where he talks about terrorism.  Mueller and Comey haveÂ an earlier association at a high-drama moment in U.S. history.Â In 2014, Comey told â€œ60 Minutesâ€ about the day that he and Mueller visited a bedridden John Ashcroft, then attorney general, to tell him they would resign rather than reauthorize a controversial domestic surveillance program under pressure from the White House. Ashcroft deferred to Comey, and, as recounted by The Los Angeles Times, â€œIt was only when President George W. Bush agreed to listen to Comey and Mueller and restructure the program did resignation plans go away.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: â€œAnd the Webby Award for Lifetime Achievement Goes toâ€¦.â€
Article: â€œThe Internet Archiveâ€¦is building a home for Universal Access to All Knowledge, open to everyone, everywhere, to use as they like. Open to all societies of the future that care to build on our triumphs and learn from our mistakes.â€ Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  â€“ Lawrence Lessig   Last night in New York City, weÂ put on our best duds and donned our fanciest archivist hats for a once in a lifetime event. TheÂ Internet Archive was honored withÂ a Lifetime AchievementÂ Award at the 21st annual Webbys, hailed by the New York Times as â€œone of the Internetâ€™s highest honors.â€ The Webby Awards laudedÂ theÂ Internet Archive for being â€œthe webâ€™s most knowledgeable historian.â€  Three of our veteran staff members, Tracey Jaquith, TV Archive Architect, Internet Archive founder and Digital Librarian, Brewster Kahle, andÂ Alexis Rossi, Director of Media and Access, accepted the award. KahleÂ delivered theÂ five-wordÂ acceptance speech with panache: Â â€œUniversal Access to All Knowledge.â€ Perhaps the greatest honor of the evening came in the form of aÂ video narratedÂ by Open Knowledge champion, Lawrence Lessig. Â He said, â€œCreativity and innovation built on the past. Â The Internet Archive is the foundation preserving that past, so that perhaps, one can at least hope that our children and their children can shape a future that knows our joys and learns from our many mistakes.â€ The award was presented by Nancy Lublin, CEO of the Crisis Text Line and DoSomething.org, who pointed out that in this chaotic politicalÂ year, the Internet Archive hasÂ saved â€œ200 terabytes of government data that could have otherwise been lost in the transition from blue light saber to red light saber.â€ The award reads: Webby Lifetime Achievement: Archive.org for its commitment to making the worldâ€™s knowledge available online and preserving the history of the Internet itself. With a vast collection of digitized materials and tools like the Wayback Machine, Archive.org has become a vital resource not only to catalogue an ever-changing medium, but to safeguard a free and open Internet for everyone. The complete list of Webby Award winners is available here.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Comey edition
Article: We devote this weekâ€™s edition of the TV News ArchiveÂ roundup to the controversy thatâ€™s erupted surrounding President Donald Trumpâ€™s sudden announcement on Tuesday, May 9, that he was firing FBI director James Comey. The TV News Archive provides a wealth of material for exploringÂ media coverage of this major moment in U.S. history. Comey fame tied to Clinton and Trump Comey may still not quite be a household name, but mention of â€œComeyâ€ spiked higher than ever onÂ TV newscastsÂ this week after he was fired. Comey has enjoyed notorietyÂ in the past, his biggest moments tied closely to the fates of 2016 presidential rivals Hillary Clinton and Trump. The most recent spike before this week was on March 20,Â when he testified before Congress, confirming that the FBI was investigating possible ties betweenÂ the TrumpÂ campaign and Russia. Another major spike occurred in November 2016, days before the election, when Comey announced the FBI was reopening an investigation into then-Democratic candidate Hillary Clintonâ€™s use of a private email server for official business while serving as secretary of state. Comey also garnered attention in July 2016, when he announced that the FBI would not be pursuing charges against Clinton. The visual below, showingÂ mentions of â€œComey,â€ was created withÂ Television Explorer, an online tool fueled by TV News Archive data and created by Kalev Leetaru. This tool can be used to find patterns in words and phrases captured by closed captioning and contained in the TV News Archive. Source: Television Explorer, Kalev Leetaru Trumpâ€™s letter to Comey fact-checked In the hours following the firing, one major point of focus for fact-checkers and other media was the portion of the letter to Comey where Trump stated, â€œWhile I greatly appreciate you informing me, on three separate occasions, that I am not under investigation, I nevertheless concur with the judgment of the Department of Justice that you are not able to effectively lead the Bureau.â€ Below is aÂ CNN broadcast, as captured in the TV News Archive, where the CNN newscaster Dave Briggs reads the letter on the air.  PolitiFact, The Washington Postâ€˜s Fact Checker, and FactCheck.org have all weighed in on the presidentâ€™s assertion, noting that too much remains unknown to confirm it. â€œWith Comey out, itâ€™s unclear whether the public will ever learn if the FBI was investigating Trump personally, rather than just his associates â€” or anything else about the investigation, for that matter,â€ wrote PolitiFactâ€™s Lauren Carroll on May 11. (See fact-checks connected to televised statements by public officials here.) Meanwhile, the story continues to unfold. On May 11, Sarah Huckabee,Â deputy White House press secretary, told ABCâ€™s George Stephanopoulos that the president had confirmed this assertion with her directly. And Trump himselfÂ told NBC Newsâ€™ Lester Holt that the assurances came during a private dinner and twice over the phone. And on FridayÂ morning, Trump tweeted that Comey â€œbetter hope there are noÂ â€˜tapesâ€™ of our conversations before he starts leaking to the press!â€ Some Watergate history, please Many commentators this week have noted parallels between Trumpâ€™s firing of Comey and the Saturday Night Massacre of 1973, when President Richard Nixon ordered independent special prosecutor Archibald Cox fired,Â during theÂ Watergate investigation; his boss, Attorney General Elliot Richardson, and Deputy General William Ruckelshaus, both of whom refused to fire Cox, resigned in protest. Acting head of the Department of Justice, Robert Bork, carried out the order to fire Cox. (Note: the Richard Nixon Library playfully, but accurately,Â fired off a tweet noting that Nixon had never fired an FBI director, and then laterÂ was criticized for doing so by theÂ National Archives and Records Administration, the federal agency that administers presidential libraries.) While the TV News Archiveâ€™s collection of 1.3 million TV news shows dates back to 2009, long after the Nixon era, some footage from that time is available from later airings. Here, for example, is footage of Coxâ€™sÂ press conference right before he was dismissed.  And here is a quick explainer of the Saturday Night Massacre, as broadcast by MSNBC in 2013.  Searching Trump Archive for past Trump statements about Comey The largely hand-curated Trump Archive, a collection of Trump statements and appearances on TV news broadcasts, makes it easier to find past instances of Trump talking about Comey. The TV News Archive is working on ways to make the creation of such collections less labor intensive, byÂ using machine learning tools to identify instances of public officials speaking within the collection of 1.3 million tv news shows. A search of closed captions on the terms â€œTrumpâ€ and â€œComeyâ€ would yield both instances when Trump is speaking about Comey and newscasters who are reporting on the two men. But searching within the Trump Archive quickly yields Trump statements about Comey.  Here is some of what we found: April 28, 2016: Trump saysÂ â€œI think if [Comeyâ€™s] Â straight up sheâ€™s not going to be able to run.â€ Â  June 13, 2016: Trump talking aboutÂ FBI investigation of Orlando nightclub shooting, â€œIâ€™m a big fan of the FBI, thereâ€™s no bigger fan than me, but look theyâ€™ve seen better days. Letâ€™s face it.â€ October 13, 2016: Â Trump speakingÂ aboutÂ Comey, â€œThe great men and women who work for the FBI are embarrassed and ashamed of what he has done to one of our truly great institutions, the FBI itself.â€ October 20, 2016: Trump at Al Smith Dinner, joking at an annual fundraiser for Catholic charities:Â Â â€œIâ€™d like to address an important religious matter, the issue of going to confession. Or, as Hillary calls it, the Fourth of July weekend with FBI director Comey.â€ October 29, 2016: Following Director Comeyâ€™s letter to congressional leaders about newly discovered Clinton emails, Trump says, â€œI have to tell you, I respect the fact that Director Comey was able to come back after what he did. I respect that very much.â€ November 14, 2016: Trump wonâ€™t say if he will ask Comey to resign. Â â€œIÂ think that I would rather not comment on that yet. I donâ€™tâ€“Â I havenâ€™t made up my mind. I respect him a lot. I respect the FBI a lot.â€ To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: Listening to the 78rpm Disc Collection
Article: By Jessica Thompson, Coast Mastering The Great 78 Project A few times a year, I join B. George in the Internet Archivesâ€™ warehouses to help sort and pack 78rpm discs to ship to George Blood L.P. for digitization. As a music fan and a professional mastering and restoration engineer, I get a thrill from handling the heavy, grooved discs, admiring the fonts and graphic designs on the labels, and chuckling at amusing song titles. Now digitized, these recordings offer a wealth of musicological, discographic and technical information, documenting and contextualizing music and recording history in the first half of the 20th century.  The sheer scale of this digitization project is unprecedented. At over 15,000 recordings and counting, the value strictly in terms of preservation is clear, especially given the Internet Archiveâ€™s focus on digitizing music less commonly available to researchers. Music fans can take a deep dive into early blues, Hawaiian, hillbilly, comedy and bluegrass. I even found several early Novachord synthesizer recordings from 1941. As a researcher and audio restoration engineer, the real goldmine is in the aggregation of discographic and technical metadata accompanying these recordings. Historians can search for and cross reference recordings based on label, artist, song title, year of release, personnel, genre, and, importantly, collection. (The Internet Archive documents the provenance of the 78rpm discs so that donated collections remain digitally intact and maintain their contextual significance.) General users can submit reviews with notes to amend or add to metadata, and the content of those reviews is searchable, so metadata collection is active. No doubt it will continue to improve as dedicated and educated users fill in the blanks. Access to the technical metadata offers a valuable teaching tool to those of us who practice audio preservation. For audio professionals new to 78s and curious about how much difference a few tenths of a millimeter of stylus can make, the Internet Archive offers 15,000+ examples of this. Play through the different styli options, and it quickly becomes apparent that particular labels, years and even discs do respond better to specific styli sizes and shapes. This is something audio preservationists are taught, but rarely are we presented with comprehensive audio examples. To be able to listen to and analyze the sonic and technical differences in these versions marries the hard science with the aesthetic. Playback speeds were not standardized until the late 1920s or early 1930s, and most discs were originally cut at speeds ranging from 76-80rpm (and some well beyond). The discs in the George Blood CollectionÂ were all digitized at a playback speed of 78rpm. Preservationists and collectors debate extensively about the â€œcorrectâ€ speed at which discs ought to be played back, and whether one ought to pitch discs individually. However, performance, recording and manufacturing practices varied so widely that even if a base speed could generally be agreed upon, there will always be exceptions. (For more on this, please check out George Bloodâ€™s forthcoming paper Stylus Size And Speed Selection In Pre-1923 Acoustic Recordings in Sustainable audiovisual collections through collaboration: Proceedings of the 2016 Joint Technical Symposium. Bloomington, IN: Indiana University Press.) Every step of making a recording involves so many aesthetic decisions â€“ choices of instrumentation, methods of sound amplification, microphone placement, the materials used in the disc itself, deliberate pitching of the instruments and slowing or speeding of the recording â€“ that playback speed simply become one of many aesthetic choices in the chain. As preservationists, we are preserving the disc as an historic record, not attempting to restore or recreate a performance. (Furthermore, speed correction is possible in the digital realm, should anyone want to modify these digital files for their own personal enjoyment). How do they sound? Each 78rpm disc has an inherent noise fingerprint based on the frequency and dynamic range the format can replicate (limited, compared to contemporary digital playback formats) and the addition of surface noise from dust, dirt and stylus wear in the grooves. As expected, the sound quality in this collection varies. Some of these discs were professionally recorded, minimally played, stored well, and play back with a tolerable, even ignorable level of surface noise relative to the musical content. Others were recorded under less professional circumstances, and/or were much loved, frequently played, stored without sleeves in basements and attics, and therefore suffer from significant surface noise that can interfere with enjoyment (and study) of the music. Yet, a compelling recording can cut through noise. Take this 1944 recording of Josh White performing St. James Infirmary, Asch 358-2A. This side has been released commercially several times, so if you look it up on a streaming service like Spotify, you can listen to different versions sourced from the same recording (though almost certainly not from the same 78rpm disc). They play at different speeds, some barely perceptibly faster or slower but at least one nearly a half-step faster than the preservation copy digitized by George Blood L.P. They also have a range of noise reduction and remastering aesthetics, some subtle and some downright ugly and riddled with digital artifacts. The version on the Internet Archive offers a benchmark. This is what the recording sounded like on the original 78rpm disc. Listen to the bend in the opening guitar notes. That technique cuts through the surface noise and should be preserved and highlighted in any restored version (which is another way of saying that any noise reduction should absolutely not interfere with the attack and decay of those luscious guitar notes).  McGill University professor of Culture and Technology Jonathan Sterne wrote a book â€“ The Audible Past: Cultural Origins of Sound Reproduction â€“ that is worth reading for anyone interested in a cultural history of early recording formats, including 78s. As Sterne says, sound fidelity is â€œultimately about deciding the values of competing and contending sounds.â€ So, in listening to digital versions of 78s on the Internet Archive, music fans, researchers, and audio professionals alike engage in a process of renegotiating concepts of acceptable thresholds of noise and what that noise communicates about the circumstances of the recording and its life on a physical disc. Fortunately, our brains are very good at calibrating to accept different ratios of signal to noise, and, I found, the more I listened to 78rpm recordings on the Internet Archive, the less I was bothered by the inherent noise. Those of us who grew up on CDs or digitally recorded and distributed music are not used to the intrusions of surface noise. However, when listening to historic recordings, we are able to adjust our expectations and process a level of noise that would be ridiculous in contemporary music formats. (Imagine this weekâ€™s Billboard Top 100 chart topper, Bruno Marsâ€™s â€œThatâ€™s What I Like,â€ with the high and low end rolled off, covered in a sheen of crackles and pops). The fact that these 78rpm recordings sound, to us, like they were made in the 1920s, 1930s, 1940s lets them get away with a different scale of fidelity. The very nature of their historicity gets them off the hook. In analog form, crackles and pops can be mesmerizing, almost like the sound of a crackling fire. However, once digitized, those previously random pops become fixed in time. What may have been enjoyable in analog form becomes a permanent annoyance in digital form. The threshold of acceptable noise levels moves again. This means that noise associated with recording carriers such as 78rpm discs is almost always preferably to noises introduced in the digital realm through the process of attempted noise reduction. Sound restorationists understand that their job is to follow a sonic Hippocratic oath: do no harm. Though noise reduction tools are widely available, they range in quality (and accordingly in cost), and are merely tools to be used with a light or heavy touch, by experienced or amateur restorationists. The question of whether noise reduction of the Internet Archiveâ€™s 78rpm recordings could be partially automated makes my heart palpitate. Though I know from experience that, for example, auto-declickers exist that could theoretically remove a layer of noise from these recordings with minimal interference with the musical signal, I donâ€™t believe the results would be uniformly satisfactory. It is so easy to destroy the aura of a recording with overzealous, heavy-handed, cheap, or simply unnecessary noise reduction. Even a gentle touch of an auto-declicker or de-crackler will have widely varying results on different recordings. I tried this with a sampling of selections from the /georgeblood/ collection. I chose eleven songs from different genres and years and ran two different, high quality auto-declickers (the iZotope RX6 Advanced multiband declicker and CEDAR Audioâ€™s declick) on the 24bit FLAC files. The results were uneven. Some of the objectively noisier songs, such as Blind Blakeâ€™s Tampa Bound, Paramount 12442-B, benefited from having the most egregious surface noises gently scrubbed.  Tampa Bound Flat Transfer vs Tampa Bound Declicked, Dehissed and Denoised thatâ€™s a lot of noise! However, a song with a strong musical presence and mild surface noise such as Trio Schmeedâ€™s Yodel Cha Cha, ABC-Paramount 9660, actually suffered more from light auto-declicking because the content of the horns and percussive elements registered to the auto-delicker as aberrations from the meat of the signal and were dulled. A pop presents as an aberration across all frequencies. Mapped visually across frequency, time and intensity, it looks like a spike cutting through the waveform. A snare hit looks similar and is therefore likely to be misinterpreted by an auto-declicker unless the threshold at which the declicker deploys is set very carefully. This difference is why good restorationists earn their pay.  Yodel Cha Cha flat transfer and denoised. Notice the â€œclicks and popsâ€ have been scrubbed, but so has wanted high end content in the music. Â I am approaching this collection as a listener and music fan, as a researcher, and as an audio professional, three very different modes of listening and interacting with music. In all cases, the Internet Archive 78rpm collection offers massive amounts of music and data to be explored, discovered, enjoyed, studied and utilized. Whether you want to listen to early Bill Monroe tunes, crackles, pops and all, or explore hundreds of recordings of pre-war polkas, or analyze the effects of stylus size on 1930s Victor discs, the Internet Archive provides the raw materials in digital form and, not to be underestimated, preserves the original discs too.

Title: Over 200 terabytes of the government web archived!
Article: In our DecemberÂ post, â€œPreserving U.S. Government Websites and Data as the Obama Term Ends,â€ we described our participation in the End of Term Web Archive project to preserve federal government websites and data at times of administrationÂ changes. We wanted to give a quick update on the project â€” we have archived a heck of a lot of data! Between Fall 2016 and Spring 2017, the Internet Archive archived over 200 terabytes of government websites and data. This includes over 100TB of public websites and over 100TB of public data from federal FTP file servers totaling, together, over 350 million URLs/files. This includes over 70 million html pages, over 40 million PDFs and,Â towards the other end of the spectrum and for semantic web aficionados, 8 files of theÂ text/turtle mime type. Other End of Term partners have also been vigorously preserving websites and data from the .gov/.mil web domains. Every web page we have archived is accessible through the Wayback Machine and we are working to add the 2016 harvest to theÂ main End of Term portalÂ soon. While we continue to analyze this collection, we posted some preliminary statistics usingÂ theÂ new Wayback Machineâ€™s summaryÂ interface forÂ this specific collection, which can be found on theÂ End of Term (EOT 2016)Â summary stats page;Â those and additional stats are served via a publicÂ EOT 2016 stats APIÂ and the full collection is also available. Through the EOT projectâ€™s public nomination form and through our collaboration with the DataRefuge,Â Environmental Data and Governance Initiative (EDGI), and other efforts, over 100,000 webpages or government datasets were nominated by citizens and preservationists for archiving. The EOT and community efforts have also garnered notableÂ press (see ourÂ End of Term 2016 Press collection). We are working with partners toÂ provide access to the full dataset for use in data mining and computational analysis and hosted a hackathon earlier this year to support use ofÂ the Obama White House Social Media datasets. While the specific End of Term collection has closed, we continue our large-scale, dedicatedÂ efforts to preserve the government web. Working with the University of North Texas, we launchedÂ the Government Web & Data Archive nomination form so the public can continue to nominate public government websites and data to be archived. Lastly, archivingÂ government data remains a critical activity of the preservation community. YouÂ can help our role in these efforts by continuing to nominate websites, promoting the EOT projectÂ via press and outreachÂ (contact the EOT project teamÂ for any inquiries), andÂ by donating to the Internet ArchiveÂ to supportÂ our ongoingÂ mission to provide â€œUniversal Access to All Knowledge.â€

Title: TV news fact-checked: Trumpâ€™s first 100 days
Article: To mark his 100th day in office, President Donald Trump made several public appearances and released a campaign-styleÂ political ad. Here are some fact-checked claims from those televised interviews, Â speeches, as well asÂ the ad, all viewable and shareable on theÂ TV News Archive. Fact-checked TV news clips on the TV News Archive. Click, watch, and share: https://archive.org/details/factchecked Fact-checking Trumpâ€™s first 100 days campaign ad President Donald Trump put his stamp of approval on this ad, which includes several factual claims. Among them: â€œFact: 500,000-plus jobs created,â€ and â€œAmerica becoming more energy independent,â€ while the wordsÂ â€œKeystone Pipelineâ€ are shown on screen. â€œUsing just the two months on his watchâ€“February and Marchâ€“the U.S. economy created 317,000 jobs, not 500,000,â€ reported Louis Jacobson for PolitiFact. â€œSamantha Gross, a fellow at the Brookings Institutionâ€™s Energy Security and Climate Initiativeâ€¦ notes that she doesnâ€™t think approving the pipeline was a bad decisionâ€¦Â  â€˜Weâ€™ve made it easier and efficient to ship that crude down to the states,â€™ though [sic.]Â the pipeline, â€˜but as far as changing energy independence, I donâ€™t think so,â€™ she said,â€ Lori Robertson reported for FactCheck.org.  Claim: first time in modern era a Supreme Court justice confirmed in first 100 days (mostly true) At the National Rifle Associationâ€™s annual meeting in Georgia on April 28, TrumpÂ said, â€œFor the first time in the modern political era, we have confirmed a new justice in the first 100 days. The last time that happened was 136 years ago, in 1881. Now, we wonâ€™t get any credit for this, but donâ€™t worry about it.â€ This statement was rated â€œmostly trueâ€ by PolitiFactâ€™s Lauren Carroll. â€œTrump has his history right. He is indeed the first modern president to fill an open Supreme Court seat within the first 100 days.â€ She went on to report â€œThe reality is that very few presidents are presented with the opportunity to appoint and confirm a new Supreme Court justice within their first 100 daysâ€¦ Trump is the only one of the group who entered office with a vacant Supreme Court seat from the startâ€”meaning he had a full 100 days to nominate and confirm his pick.â€  Claim: U.S. has a $17 billion trade deficit with Canada (no, itâ€™s a surplus) President Trump sat down with FOXâ€™s Martha MacCallum for their â€œThe First 100 Daysâ€ interview. In it, Trump said â€œThe trade deficit with Mexico is close to $70 billion, even with Canada itâ€™s $17 billion trade deficit with Canada.â€ The reporters at FactCheck.org, though, found that â€œFor the second year in a row, the U.S. had a trade surplus with Canada. In 2016, the U.S. had an $8.1 billion trade surplus in goods and services with Canada, up nearly 33 percent from the $6.1 billion surplus in 2015.â€  Claim: Trump has negative media coverage because reporters donated to Clinton (misleading) The president spoke to a large crowd in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, where he cited a study by the conservative Media Research CenterÂ talking about negative coverage of his administration. He then suggested the reason was â€œperhaps thatâ€™s because, according to the Center for Public Integrity, 96 percent of journalists who made donations in the last election gave them to our opponent.â€ FactCheck.org reported that the Center for Public Integrity study showed â€œthat about 430 people â€˜who work in journalismâ€™ contributed about $382,000 to the Clinton campaign through August, compared with about 50 journalists who contributed $14,000 to Trump. Notably, however, the study did not find that anyÂ journalists responsible for covering the White House, Congress or national politics made political contributions of any kind.â€  Claim: people with pre-existing conditions are covered in the House GOP health care bill (unclear) In an interview for CBSâ€™s Face the Nation, President Trump said, â€œPre-existing conditions are in the bill. And I just watched another network than yours, and they were saying, â€˜Pre-existing is not covered.â€™ Pre-existing conditions are in the bill. And I mandate it. I said, â€˜Has to be.'â€ PolitiFactâ€™s Amy Sherman reviewedÂ andÂ ratedÂ this claim â€œmostly false,â€ reporting â€œOverall, the latest proposal seems to weaken existing protections for people with pre-existing conditions, not strengthen them.â€ An amendment was proposed since then, and Glenn Kessler summarized the new proposalÂ for the Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, writing, â€œif the bill ever became law, much would depend on unknown policy decisions by individual statesâ€“and then how those decisions are implemented.â€ This proposal had a House vote yesterday, Thursday, and passed.  How to findÂ Trumpâ€™s 100th-day TV news appearances To review the 100 days interviews and speeches yourself and grab the clips you want, check outÂ this Fox interview in two parts, the Harrisburg, PA speech, the NRA address, the Face the Nation interview in two parts, the â€œCBS This Morningâ€ interview in two parts, and Trumpâ€™sÂ weekly address. Trumpâ€™s Harrisburg address, as seen in context in the TV News Archive. Note Trump icon on top left, showing this show is part of the Trump Archive. To peruse all the fact-checking work our partners have done on statements made on TV and archived in the TV News Archive, take a look at this table of more than 800 fact-checks of Donald Trump, his administration, and some congressional leaders. This collection will continue to grow as we develop the congressional collections, add more administration official statements, and integrate new statements and reporting. To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: TV news fact-checked: Ivanka, McCaskill, Mnuchin, Perez, and Mulvaney
Article: By Katie Dahl This weekâ€™s roundup includes fiveÂ fact-checks of statements by public officials, preservedÂ on TV News Archive. Our fact-checking partners examined the financial disclosures of the president, who outspent whom in the Georgia election, and whether high ranking Democrats voted for a border wall a decade ago. Claim: Child care is the largest expense in more thanÂ half of American households (mostly false) Ivanka Trump, first daughter and adviser to President Donald Trump, participated in a panel in Berlin with German President Angela Merkel. While there, she said the â€œsingle largest expense in over half of American households is childcare, even exceeding the cost of housing.â€ â€œChild Care Aware, a trade and advocacy group, found that it cost on average over $17,000 a year for infant day care in Massachusetts,â€ reportedÂ Jon Greenberg for PolitiFact. â€œThe question is, does paying for child care top all the other expenses that half of the households have to cover, such as housing and food?â€¦Government data suggests it does not. For most families, the No. 1 cost is housing.â€ The Washington Postâ€˜s Fact Checker, Glenn Kessler, also reported,â€[S]he would have been on more solid ground if she had focused on low-income households or families with small children, not all households.â€  Claim: Nobody applies to the U.S. for refugee status. They apply to the U.N. (false) â€œNobody applies to the United States for refugee status. They apply to the United Nations,â€ saidÂ Sen. Claire McCaskill, D., Mo., during a January senate hearing for Rex Tillersonâ€™s nomination as Secretary of State. PolitiFact Missouri reporter Aleissa Bleyl reportedÂ this week that â€œabout 20 percent to 30 percent of resettlement cases are handled by the United States and not the U.Nâ€¦ Overall, most refugees seeking resettlement to the United States must first go through the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. However, refugees with nuclear family members already living in the United States are given a different priority that isnâ€™t processed through the United Nations.â€  Claim: Trump has given more financial disclosure than anybody else (false) After receiving a question about whether the president would release his tax returns, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said, â€œThe president has no intentionâ€¦ The president has released plenty of information and, I think, has given more financial disclosure than anybody else. I think the American population has plenty of information.â€ Allison Graves and Louis JacobsonÂ rated Mnuchinâ€™s statement as â€œFalse,â€ reporting for PolitiFact, â€œTrump released a financial disclosure report that all presidential candidates are required to fill out, but the fact that Trump has not released any tax filings undermines Munchinâ€™s claimâ€¦ the lack of transparency around his tax returns remains a significant omission compared with recent presidents.â€  Claim: Ossof was outspent two to one in Georgia race (unsupported) Neither candidate received enough votes to win outright in the race for Georgiaâ€™s 6th Congressional District, in a special election to replace Tom Price, who now heads the U.S. Department ofÂ Health and Human Services. Â A runoff is now scheduled for June. Explaining the outcome, Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez said,â€œBy the way, Chris, he was outspent two to one. I mean Paul Ryanâ€™s super PAC was in. They hit the panic button big-time on the Republican side.â€ But, â€œthe Federal Election Commission campaign finance records donâ€™t support his claim that Ossoff was â€˜outspent two to one.â€™â€ According to Eugene Kiely and Robert Farley at FactCheck.org, â€œOssoff and the outside groups who supported him spent more than the Republican groups that opposed him.â€   Claim: Obama, Schumer, and Clinton voted for a border wall in 2006 (half true) White House budget director Mick Mulvaney recently defended proposed funding for a border wall between the United States and Mexico. â€œWe still donâ€™t understand why the Democrats are so wholeheartedly against it. They voted for it in 2006. Then-Sen. Obama voted for it. Sen. Schumer voted for it. Sen. Clinton voted for it,â€ he said. â€œThey did vote for the Secure Fence Act of 2006, which authorized building a fence along about 700 miles of the border between the United States and Mexico,â€ reported Allison Graves for PolitiFact. â€œStill, the fence they voted for is not as substantial as the wall Trump is proposing. Trump himself called the 2006 fence a â€˜nothing wall.â€™â€  Follow us on twitter! Weâ€™ve changed our nameÂ from @PolitAdArchive to @TVNewsArchive.  Weâ€™ve changed our handle! @PolitAdArchive now @TVNewsArchive.
