Search our public, online TV news collection: https://t.co/ZzphyYE0xk pic.twitter.com/RfeyrIyTSu â€” TV News Archive (@TVNewsArchive) April 28, 2017  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: CANCELED: Hitting the Wall: How the Media Shapes the Immigration Debate
Article: We are incredibly disappointed to have to tell you all that, due to last minute unforeseen scheduling conflicts, the â€œHitting The Wallâ€ event has been cancelled. We know that many of you (us included!) were looking forward to the event and feel very passionately about this topic but circumstances beyond our control have made it necessary to cancel at this time. We appreciate your kind understanding and hope to see you at future events.  ______________________________________________ How can we tell fact from fiction when it comes to a controversial topic like immigration? Join us at the Internet Archive for an evening with experienced journalists from the Center for Investigative Reporting (CIR) and Retro Report, who will work with the audience to develop strategies to fight back against propaganda and fake news. Admission is $10 and includes tacos, beer, wine, and soda: When: Wednesday, May 17th Doors open at 5:30 p.m. for food and drinks, and discussion starts at 7 p.m.   Where: Internet Archive  300 Funston Ave. SF, CA 94118 The program will take place in three acts. Act 1: The Story In Act 1, weâ€™ll go deep on the facts and stories about immigration in the U.S. What does the data tell us about immigration in the U.S.? Who is coming and who is going and what are the trends for both? What is the mission of the U.S. Border Patrol? What would it actually mean to build a wall along the entire U.S.-Mexico Border? What does the term â€œsanctuary cityâ€ mean? Act 2: The Challenge In Act 2, weâ€™ll work with the audience to find practical strategies to make the public debate over immigration fact-based and productive. The CIR and Retro Report teams will work with the audience to hone in on key questions in the immigration debate, with special attention for the points of tension in the immigration debate. Â What are common misunderstandings about immigration? How and why do they emerge? Act 3: Solutions In Act 3, weâ€™ll do a group brainstorm on how to burst filter bubbles and work for constructive debate and change on immigrationâ€“and other issues  With the audience, the journalists will identify practical strategies they can take back to the newsroom and share with other media when reporting on controversial issues. How can the media work directly with communities, provide trustworthy reporting on a complex issue, and help the public recognize fake news? Get Tickets Here  Retro Report is an award-winning, digital-first documentary news organization dedicated to bringing context to todayâ€™s headlines by telling the story behind the news; it is non-partisan, independent and non-profit. Â Retro Report is founded on the conviction that without an engaging and forward-looking review of high-profile events and the news coverage surrounding them, we lose a critical opportunity to understand the lessons of history.Â  In a culture increasingly disposed towards trending news and Twitter-sized sound bites, the importance of that mission is amplified.Â Retro Report has produced more than 100 short documentaries and video series and partnered with The New York Times, PBS, NBC, Politico, the Guardian, Univision and others.Â   The mission of The Center for Investigative Reporting is to engage and empower the public through investigative journalism and groundbreaking storytelling in order to spark action, improve lives and protect our democracy. Founded in 1977 as the nationâ€™s first nonprofit investigative journalism organization, we are celebrating our 40th anniversary this year. Over those four decades, we have developed a reputation for being among the most innovative, credible and relevant media organizations in the country. Reveal â€“ our website, public radio program, podcast and social media platform â€“ is where we publish our multiplatform work.

Title: Celebrate a major advance in access to knowledge in India and America â€” Wednesday, June 14 6PM in SF
Article: By Carl Malamud WATCH THE FULL VIDEO HERE  Please join us on June 14 at the Internet Archive for a special event celebrating our collections from India including the collected works of Mahatma Gandhi and much, much more. Our doors open at 6 p.m. with a reception and our program starts promptly at 7 p.m. Our special guest for this event will be Hon. Dr. Sam Pitroda, a former senior advisor and Cabinet Minister under 3 Prime Ministers and widely acknowledged as the father of the telecommunications revolution in India, the man who brought a telephone to every village in India. Dr. Pitroda will be joined by Hon. Ambassador Venkatesan Ashok, Consul-General of San Francisco. Rounding out our program will be Carl Malamud of Public Resource and the Internet Archiveâ€™s own Brewster Kahle. Our event will be celebrating three collections hosted at the Internet Archive: First, the Internet Archive is delighted to be hosting a mirror of the Digital Library of India, a collection of 463,000 books in 50 languages. The collection was created in India under government auspices and features 45,000 books in Hindi, 33,000 in Sanskrit, 30,160 in Bengali, and much more. In addition to hosting a mirror of the collection, the Internet Archive is adding value to the collection by creating e-books, using optical character recognition, and improving the metadata and cataloging information. Second, we will feature the Hind Swaraj collection, materials that are integral to the story of Indian independence. Here you can read all 100 volumes of the Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi, as well as the complete writings of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Jawaharlal Nehru. You can also listen to 129 audio recordings from All India Radio of Gandhiji speaking at prayer meetings and view all 53 episodes of the remarkable television series Bharat Ek Khoj. Third, we will discuss additional collections of Indian materials, such as thousands of photographs from the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting and other sources which Public Resource hosts on Flickr and a collection of all technical public safety India Standards hosted on the Internet Archive and the Public Resource site. Carl Malamud and Sam Pitroda have spent several years building out these collections. We hope you will join us at this event to hear more about how this came to pass and what the plans are for making this material ever more useful. We also hope to have some exciting announcements as well about new resources that will be available.  Universal access to knowledge is the goal of the Internet Archive. We are delighted to celebrate the immense contributions of India and the vital role both India and the United Statesâ€”the worldâ€™s largest democraciesâ€”play in make knowledge available to all. Please join us on June 14! When: Wednesday, June 14th. Doors open at 6 p.m. for food and drinks, and program starts at 7 p.m. Where: Internet Archive 300 Funston Ave. SF, CA 94118

Title: TV News Lab: Hyperaudio improving TV news video captioning and sharing
Article: In a new blog series, TV News Lab, weâ€™ll demonstrate how the Internet Archive is partnering with technology, journalism, and academic organizations to experiment with and improve the TV News Archive, our free, public, online library of TV news shows. Here we interview Mark Boas, founder of the Hyperaudio project, an organization that works to make audio and video more accessible and shareable on the web, by providing an easy-to-use interface for copying and pasting bits of transcripts to create mash ups of shareable video. You can find the open source codeÂ powering Hyperaudio on GitHub. Mark Boas talks to the Internet Archive about Hyperaudio. NW: What is the problem youâ€™re trying to solve by applying Hyperaudio technology to the TV News Archive? MB: People find TV news credible. Itâ€™s very hard to fake TV news. Iâ€™d love to see people using TV news to back up any sort of political or other expression a public official is trying to make, by showing the source material and also the arguments about those statements. I think this also has implications for improving media literacy. (An example mix made at Chattanooga Public Library.) NW: What stands in the way of people sharing TV news video right now? MB: Â One of the problems is that audio and video on the web has been a black box in a way. It has not been very well integrated into the web because itâ€™s difficult to do that. If you see a big block of text, itâ€™s easy to highlight, copy, paste and send it off. But if you have an interesting piece of audio to share, how do you do that? There are ways to do it, but itâ€™s not intuitive. Coupled with that is itâ€™s also hard to find audio on the internet. If youâ€™re searching for search terms, you may or may not find what you want, but only if someone has added sufficient metadata so itâ€™s discoverable. Transcripts allow you to search, but also provide a way to share. And the key to that is that you need not just the transcript, but also you need to match the words in the transcript to the proper times in the audio. NW: Why is it hard to match the transcript to the audio in a video? The first step is getting a good quality transcript. Itâ€™s great that the TV News Archive uses open captions, but itâ€™s not perfect. (Note: the TV News Archive is searchable via closed captioning, but thereâ€™s often a several-second lag between the captions and the video, as well as other quality issues.) The transcript usually needs to be cleaned up. The better the transcript, the better the match. Closed captions are done in real time by humans who make mistakes. The next challenge is to try and minimize the time it takes to match the words in the transcript to the audio. If we want to automate the process, we need to figure out how to do that more quickly. Itâ€™s very intensive on the computing side. Iâ€™m experimenting with chunking up the video to speed up the process. I think weâ€™ll see that the matching is an exponential task: a one hour transcript might take 30 minutes and a three hour transcript might take more than three times that. But if we split it up into smaller chunks, the processing might become more efficient How do people try out Hyperaudio? Hyperaudio is not a commercial software as a service. Itâ€™s more of a demo of the underlying technology. We work with groups like the Studs Terkel Radio Archive (WFMT Chicago), to help them make the most of their content and data; whatever we make flows back into our open source code on GitHub. What we do is very experimental, but it will give you an idea whatâ€™s possible. If you want to experiment with TV News Archive, you can do that at http://newsarchive.hyperaud.io/. More info on our experiments and collaborations can be found on our blog.

Title: Internet Archive wins Webby Lifetime Achievement award
Article: We are honored to announce that the Internet Archive has been named as one of the 21st annual Webby Awards winners! Hailed as one of the Internetâ€™s highest honors, weâ€™re excited to receive a Webby Lifetime Achievement award and join the ranks of our friends like Sir Tim Berners-Lee, Lawrence Lessig, and Vint Cerf. Webby Lifetime Achievement: Archive.org for its commitment to making the worldâ€™s knowledge available online and preserving the history of the Internet itself. With a vast collection of digitized materials and tools like the Wayback Machine, Archive.org has become a vital resource not only to catalogue an ever-changing medium, but to safeguard a free and open Internet for everyone. We thank the International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences for the award and are looking forward to attending the Webby Awards in New York City on May 15. The complete list of Webby Award winners is available here.

Title: Macintosh Collection Hand-Screenshottedâ€¦ Plus: HyperCard!
Article: The Internet Archiveâ€™s emulated Early Mac collection, which was announced last week, has had all its content screenshotted by hand for maximum visual beauty and accuracy. Normally, we utilize a set of automated scripts that do screenshotting, allowing for a large amount of uploads to be visually described, but the combination of many different permutations of where to click and which folders to open meant we werenâ€™t getting the best shots for each item. Now, theyâ€™re doing justice to the unique and interesting early Mac experience.  Like many other cases in computer history, the seeming limitations of black-and-white-only screens on early Macintoshes gave rise to truly beautiful and complicated art, which expressed itself crisply on the 9-inch monitors.  Response to the earlyÂ Macintosh collection has been resoundingly positive; thanks again to all the volunteers who helped the system work as well as it does. With 60+ titles added and more to come, this is likely to be one of our most memorable and stellar playable software collections on the Archive. But one more thingâ€¦. Throughout the testing process and discussions about emulating Macintosh, a steady drumbeat of requests could be summarized as: â€œWhat about HyperCard?â€ HyperCard, a hypertext authoring system for the Macintosh, is a legendary environment for creating â€œStacksâ€, which were clickable cards with a wide range of options and features. It is absolutely the inspiration for what ultimately became the World Wide Web. It was possible to write truly complicated and complete applications in HyperCard, and stacks allowing everything from reference books to games to music â€“ whatever the authors of stacks could come with. It was particularly popular with academics and writers. A great retrospective of HyperCard at its 25th anniversary was written by Ars Technica. So.. what about HyperCard? Yes, we have HyperCard.  The Emularity Loader utilized by the Internet Archive allows the combining of the content of two items in the Archiveâ€™s collections, meaning there can be a â€œgeneral boot diskâ€ with HyperCard, and then pulling in an uploaded Hypercard Stack. As of this writing, weâ€™ve added a small number of Stacks to prove the technology, including the â€œBeerStackâ€ beer-reference, the Adventures of SeanÂ (an interactive cartoon), and a re-created Stack designed by none other than Douglas Adams for calculating the volume of a Megapode nest.  Adding new stacks is relatively complicated, and weâ€™re working on adding more from such sites as HYPERCARD.ORGÂ who have been gathering amazing Stacks for years.Â If youâ€™re someone who worked on a HyperCard stack in the past, or oversee a collection of Stacks created by others, please feel free to contact hypercard@textfiles.com to receive assistance in adding your stacks, emulated, to the Archive. We hope this is the start of a large, quality collection of emulated programs at the Archive around the Macintosh, and thank you for spreading the word about it, and the importance of providing instant worldwide access to historical software. A shout-out to volunteer Stephen ColeÂ who has taken on the mantle of adding new titles to the Macintosh collection over time, including the ingestion of HyperCard stacks.

Title: TV news highlights: visitor logs, voter turnout, China, North Korea, United Airlines
Article: By Katie Dahl In this weekâ€™s look back at TV news highlights that have been fact-checked by our partners, we get a history of the White House policy on releasing visitor logs; a look at how 2016 voter turnout compared to other elections; an examination of whether United Airlines was contractually obliged against removing a ticketed passenger; a comparison of U.S. vs. ChinaÂ on their polluting record;Â and an analysis of how positively China regardsÂ Trumpâ€™s recent actions on North Korea. Claim: In not releasing visitor logs to the public, the White House is following the same policy as every U.S. administration â€œfrom the beginning of timeâ€ except Obama (true) Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the White Housesâ€™s announcementÂ it would not be releasing names ofÂ White House visitors to the public,Â saying, â€œI think as was noted on Friday, weâ€™re following the same policy that every administration from the beginning of time has used with respect to visitor logs.â€ Later in that daily press briefing, he refined his statement:Â â€œ[I]tâ€™s the same policy that every administration had up until the Obama administration.â€ Former President Barack Obamaâ€™s decision to make visitor logs public was done in the name of transparencyâ€“although only after pressure from outside groups, explained Louis Jacobson for PolitiFact. But Spicer is correct that â€œ[h]istorically speaking, the policy under Obama was the exception, rather than the rule.â€  Claim: Voter turnout for theÂ 2016 presidential raceÂ was theÂ lowest in 20 years (false) On CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union,â€ Sen. Bernie Sanders, D., Vt., talked aboutÂ his national tour to increase civic participation, citing a statistic on voting turnout: â€œSo many of our people are giving up on the political process. It is very frightening. In the last presidential election, when Trump won, we had the lowest voter turnout over â€” in 20 years. And in the previous two years before that, in the midterm election, we had the lowest voter turnout in 70 years.â€ â€œIn fact, turnout was higher than it was in 2012,â€ according to Eugene Kiely at FactCheck.org. PolitiFactâ€™s Jacobson confirmedÂ that Sanders was wrong on the claim that 2016 had the â€œlowest turnoutâ€ in the last 20 years, but correct that 2014 saw the lowest turnout in 70 years.Â Both reportersÂ cited the work of Michael McDonald, a political scientist at the University of Florida.  Claim: United Airlines passenger had a right to stay on the plane (false) After United Airlines violently removed paying passenger David Dao from a plane to make room for employees, syndicated columnist Andrew Napolitano said on Fox News: â€œBy dislodging this passenger against his will, United violated its contractual obligation. He paid for the ticket, he bought the ticket, he passed the TSA, he was in his seat, he has every right to stay there.â€ â€œFalse,â€ wroteÂ Joshua Gillan forPunditFact, a project of PolitiFact.Â â€œNapolitanoâ€™s blanket assertion is incorrect. Experts told us that airlines, including United, outline dozens of reasons why they might remove a passenger after he has already boarded.â€  Claim: China and India pollute more than the United States (four Pinocchios) During a recent TV interview, Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt said, â€œChina and India had no obligations under the [Paris Accord] agreement until 2030.â€ He also claimed that â€œ[Europe, China, India] are polluting way more than we are.â€ â€œ[B]oth countries pledge to reach these goals by 2030, meaning they are taking steps now to meet their commitments,â€ reported Glenn Kessler for TheÂ Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker. â€œChina (but not India) does produce more carbon dioxide than the United States, but it has nearly 1.4 billion people compared to 325 million for the United States. So, on a per capita basis, the United States in 2015 produced more than double the carbon dioxide emissions of China â€” and eight times more than India.â€  Claim: Trump on North Korea: â€œWeâ€™ve never seen such a positive response on our behalf from Chinaâ€ (half true) Defending his decision to step back from labeling China a currency manipulator, President Donald Trump said he is working with China on a â€œbigger problem,â€ North Korea, and that the result is good, claiming, â€œ[N]obody has ever seen such a positive response on our behalf from China.â€ PolitiFactâ€™s Jon Greenberg sharedÂ results of interviews with several experts as support for his rating of â€œhalf trueâ€ for the claim: â€œIt is difficult to quantify a â€˜positive response.â€™ Whether the latest moves represent a sea shift that â€˜no one has ever seen,â€™ or the logical conclusion of a longer pattern, probably lies in the eye of the beholder.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: Find Oâ€™Reilly Factor clips on TV News Archive
Article: With yesterdayâ€™sÂ announcement Fox News had oustedÂ Bill Oâ€™ReillyÂ from the helm of â€œThe Oâ€™Reilly Factor,â€ following mounting complaints of sexual harassment, the pugilistic hostâ€™sÂ reign as the â€œking of cable newsâ€ passes into history. However, a good portion ofÂ that American political history isÂ preserved for posterity as part of the TV News Archive, the Internet Archiveâ€™s searchable collection of television news. Weâ€™ve got someÂ 3,000 hours of â€œThe Oâ€™Reilly Factorâ€ dating back to 2009, Â including at least 20 segments that have been fact-checked by PolitiFact. Perhaps Oâ€™Reilly described his mission best with his response to a viewer, who urged him in October 2016, â€œStick to the facts, not your personal opinion.â€Â Said Oâ€™Reilly: â€œThe Oâ€™Reilly factor is built around my personal opinions, sir. Twenty yearsâ€¦thus the name: â€˜The Oâ€™Reilly Factor.'â€  Here are severalÂ fact-checked Oâ€™Reilly highlights from recent years: Guns. Â Oâ€™Reilly claimed that Â Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland â€œvoted, so the folks know, in Washington, D.C., to keep guns away from private citizens.â€ PunditFact: â€œFalseâ€¦.Garland didnâ€™t vote on this case at all.â€ (March 2016.)  Crime.Â From 2014 to 2015, said Oâ€™Reilly in October 2015, Austinâ€™s â€œmurder rate is up a whopping 83 percent.â€ PolitiFact Texas: Mostly False. â€œ[I]f Oâ€™Reilly had pulled back the camera, so to speak, he could have determined that Austin appears on pace to have a lower murder rate in 2015 than in 2014.â€  Iran, China, and Russia.Â Oâ€™Reilly:Â Russia and China â€œabsolutely said pretty clearlyâ€ they would not keep economic sanctions on Iran if the United States â€œwalked away from the deal.â€ This time Oâ€™Reilly earned a â€œMostly True,â€ from PolitiFact: â€œOâ€™Reilly is pushing the envelope when he said â€œabsolutelyâ€ clear, as they havenâ€™t issued formal statements. But all of their actions indicate that what Oâ€™Reilly said is substantially accurate.â€   Muslims cheering 9-11. â€œThousands of Muslims, regular folks, celebrated in the streetsâ€¦ . these people are a minority but they were not called out in any official way by Muslim nations around the world.â€ PolitiFact: â€œHalf True.â€ â€œSo far as we can tell, there was no official condemnation of people celebrating the 9/11 attacks. However, Muslim governments, and religious leaders, condemned the attacks themselves, as did many average Muslims.â€  Thereâ€™s more!Â Popcorn fact-check annotation experiment For a reel of fact-checks of Oâ€™Reilly statements over the years, check out this compilation created with a recent version of Mozillaâ€™sÂ Popcorn editorÂ by TV News Archive Director Roger Macdonald. Popcorn allows viewers to feed TV News Archive video into an editor and mix it up with other videos, add text annotations, hyperlinks, and more. We believe this is a glimpse of the future: giving people the tools to put the messages that bombard them in context, rather than being passive viewers. MozillaÂ launchedÂ the innovative tool in 2012; while they no longer support it, the source code is open for others to improve. Please be patient withÂ occasional buffering glitches. Â Try clicking on some of the text for links and the orange quote icon link to citations. Â And, if you want to go wild, click the arrows triangle icon and try your hand at remixing.  If impatient with problems playing the Popcorn version, here is a plain-old mp4. Â No embedded links or remix options.

Title: DRM for the Web is a Bad Idea
Article: I asked our crawler folks what the impact of the EME proposal could be to us, and what they came back with seems well reasoned but strongly negative to our mission. I have posted the analysis below for the public to consider. -brewster At your request we have assessed what the possible effects of the Encrypted Media Extensions (EME) as a W3C recommendation would be. We believe it will be dangerous to the open web unless protections are put in place for those who engage in activities, such as archiving, that are threatened by the legal regime governing the standard. One major issue is that people who bypass EME, even for legitimate reasons, have reason to fear retaliation under section 1201 of the US Digital Millennium Copyright Act, and laws like it around the world, such as Article 6 of the European Union Copyright Directive, which indiscriminately bar circumvention even for lawful purposes. Locking up standards-defined video streams with digital rights management (DRM) could put our archiving activities at serious risk. DRM, which imposes technological restrictions that control what users can do with digital media, is antithetical to the open web. Moreover, EME opens the possibility that DRM could spread to non-video content such as typography or images, which poses an even more existential threat. Web archiving and the Wayback Machine would suffer. Archiving is not the only activity endangered by anti-circumvention laws and EME: from accessibility adaptation to security research to the kinds of legitimate innovative activities that you began your career with â€” inventing the first search engines â€” the normal course of the open, standards-defined internet is incompatible with the anti-circumvention regime that comes into play if the W3C publishes EME as a recommendation. The Electronic Frontier Foundation has proposed a sensible and simple compromise: binding W3C members not to invoke anti-circumvention laws unless there is some other cause of action. This preserves the legitimate interests of rightsholders against those who trespass on their copyrights, trade secrets and contractual obligations, without turning the W3C standards process into a backdoor to creating new legal rights to prevent legitimate, vital activities. Every organization involved in creating and preserving the open web is facing unprecedented challenges and pressures today. It is up to the guardians of the open web to meet those challenges with an unwavering commitment to our core principles: that the web must be free for anyone to write, to read, to connect to, to adapt, to archive and to preserve. As such, I recommend that we object to the publication of EME as a W3C specification without safeguarding these foundational principles of the open web.

Title: Robots.txt meant for search engines donâ€™t work well for web archives
Article: Robots.txt files were invented 20+ years ago to help advise â€œrobots,â€ mostly search engine web crawlers, which sections of a web site should be crawled and indexed for search.  Many sites use their robots.txt files to improve their SEO (search engine optimization) by excluding duplicate content like print versions of recipes, excluding search result pages, excluding large files from crawling to save on hosting costs, or â€œhidingâ€ sensitive areas of the site like administrative pages. (Of course, over the years malicious actors have also used robots.txt files to identify those same sensitive areas!) Â Some crawlers, like Google, pay attention to robots.txt directives, while others do not.  Over time we have observed that the robots.txt files that are geared toward search engine crawlers do not necessarily serve our archival purposes. Â Internet Archiveâ€™s goal is to create complete â€œsnapshotsâ€ of web pages, including the duplicate content and the large versions of files. Â We have also seen an upsurge of the use of robots.txt files to remove entire domains from search engines when they transition from a live web site into a parked domain, which has historically also removed the entire domain from view in the Wayback Machine. Â In other words, a site goes out of business and then the parked domain is â€œblockedâ€ from search engines and no one can look at the history of that site in the Wayback Machine anymore. Â We receive inquiries and complaints on these â€œdisappearedâ€ sites almost daily. A few months ago we stopped referring to robots.txt files on U.S. government and military web sites for both crawling and displaying web pages (though we respond to removal requests sent to info@archive.org). As we have moved towards broader access it has not caused problems, which we take as a good sign. Â We are now looking to do this more broadly. Â  We see the future of web archiving relying less on robots.txt file declarations geared toward search engines, and more on representing the web as it really was, and is, from a userâ€™s perspective.

Title: TV News highlights: sanctuary cities, cabinet wealth, and more
Article: By Katie Dahl In our weekly highlights reel of fact-checked TV appearances by public officials, we feature our fact-checking partnersâ€™ reportsÂ onÂ sanctuary cities, what Roger Stone knew about the Podesta emails, the financial wealth of Trumpâ€™s cabinet, the loss of U.S. factories as a result of China joining the World Trade Organization, and the percentage of the Texas state budget spent on Medicaid. Claim: 80% of Americans oppose sanctuary cities (depends on the question) On March 27, Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a new policy: the U.S. Department of Justice would startÂ holding back funding from citiesâ€“known asÂ â€œsanctuary citiesâ€“that donâ€™t enforce immigration law. In doing so, heÂ cited public opinion polling: â€œAccording to one recent poll, 80 percent of Americans believe that cities that arrest illegal immigrants for a crime should be required to turn them over to immigration authorities.â€ White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer has also usedÂ this statistic. Providing context, Michelle YeÂ Hee Lee wroteÂ forÂ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, â€œThereâ€™s no perfect polling question, and we recognize sanctuary policies and immigration detainers are not easily distilled into one question.â€ She noted that other polls show thatÂ â€œwhen specifically asked about pulling federal funding from sanctuary citiesâ€ just 42 percent of Americans agreed. She also pointed out that the 80 percent figure comes from a poll using an opt-in Web panel sample, â€œwhich we often warn readers againstÂ relying onâ€ unless other measures have proven it accurate over time.  Claim: Roger Stone predicted John Podesta would be a victim of a Russian hack (no evidence) At a hearing on March 20, Rep. Adam, Schiff, D., Calif., said, â€œIs it a coincidence that Roger Stone predicted that John Podesta would be a victim of a Russian hack and have his private emails published, and did so even before Mr. Podesta himself was fully aware that his private emails would be exposed?â€ Writing for FactCheck.org, Robert Farley reports that one of these assertions is not established fact: â€œThere is nothing in the public record so far that proves Stone, a political operative and longtime Trump associate, predicted the Podesta email hackâ€¦â€ â€œStone says his Aug. 21 tweet about Podestaâ€”that it would soon be Podestaâ€™s â€˜time in the barrelâ€™ â€” had nothing to do with hacked emails, though. Two days prior, Trumpâ€™s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, quit the campaign amid media reports about prior business dealings with Russia-aligned leaders in Ukraine. Stone said he was aware that Podesta also had business ties to Russia, and that journalists were beginning to look into those. Thatâ€™s what prompted the tweet, he said.â€  Claim: Trump cabinet worth more than 100 million Americans (mostly true) While talking about the presidentâ€™s budget proposal and calling into question his campaign promiseÂ to â€œdrain the swamp,â€ Sen. Chuck Schumer, D., N.Y., claimed that â€œif you add up the net wealth of his cabinet, it has more wealth than a third of the American people totalâ€“close to 100 million people.â€ PolitiFactâ€™s Jana Heigl reported that although â€œ[i]t is impossible to calculate the exact net wealth of Trumpâ€™s cabinetâ€¦ It also doesnâ€™t really matter how rich Trumpâ€™s cabinet members exactly are.â€ According to Gabriel Zucman, an economist at the University of Berkeley, â€œâ€˜The bottom one-third of American households ranked by wealth own approximately nothing.â€™â€ Heigl added that itâ€™s â€œâ€˜because some either have a very low or even negative net wealth, due to high debt.â€™â€ She concluded â€œâ€˜it does not take a lot to â€˜have more wealth than a third of the American people,â€™ like Schumer claimed, Zuchman added.â€  Claim: U.S. lost 60,000 factories since China joined WTO (mostly true) During a speech in Louisville, Ky., President Donald TrumpÂ claimed: â€œSince China joinedâ€”thatâ€™s another beautyâ€”the WTO in 2001, the U.S. has lost many more than 60,000 factories.â€ Lauren Carroll reported for PolitiFact that â€œthe United States has, in fact, lost more than 60,000 factories since 2001, when China joined the WTO and became a bigger player in the world economy. And quite a few economists believe opening up trade with China has had a significant and negative effect on American manufacturing, though itâ€™s not a universal view.â€ However, Â economic historian Bradford DeLong with the University of California, Berkeley, told PolitiFact, â€œabout one-tenth of factory closures over the past decade or so have had to do with China, but that would have happened whether or not China joined the WTO.â€  Claim: Texas spent close toÂ 1/3 its budget on Medicaid last year (mostly true) While advocating the passage of the American Health Care Act, Rep. John Cornyn, R., Tex., said,Â  â€œWe know that the states and the federal government spend an awful lot of money on Medicaid. In Texas, for example, my state spent close to a third of its budget on Medicaid last year, a third of all state spending.â€ According to a report from the Texas Legislative Budget Board, as reported by PolitiFactâ€™s W. Gardner Selby, â€œthe 2016-17 Texas budget devoted $61.2 billion in funds from all sources, including state and federal aid, to Medicaidâ€¦ and that amount over the two years running through August 2017 accounted for 29.3 percent of $209.1 billion in All Funds appropriations.â€ If you narrow the view to Texas funds spent on Medicaid, â€œ22 percent of state funds alone was appropriated for Medicaid.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribeÂ here.

Title: Books Donated for MacArthur Foundation 100&Change Challenge from BookMooch Users
Article: Thank you, Richard from Georgia, for Theories of Development. Thank you to the people that are starting to send books to the Internet Archive to be digitized.Â  The Internet Archive digitizes already, but as semifinalists for a $100million grant from the MacArthur Foundation, we are ramping up. Our proposal is to bring 4 million of the most beloved and important books to learners by helping all libraries become digital libraries. Bookmooch is an online book exchange community whose members list what books they have and which books they want. When you send a book, you earn a point, toÂ receive a book you spend a point. Some people have surplus points which they have generously donated to the Internet Archive to help us build our collection. To start on our 4 million book quest we are looking at the most assigned books on course syllabi (as aggregated by the OpenSyllabus project).Â  We gave this list to the founder of BookMooch, John Buckman and he found 61,000 were held by community members and hundreds available right now. Thank you, Suzanne from North Carolina, for Independence and Nationhood: Scotland, 1306-1469 The first books are starting to arrive, and there is much rejoicing!Â  Onward! Thank you to Cindy from Massachusetts for Holy Land: A Suburban Memoir Thank you, S Krashen, from California for Language Two

Title: TV News highlights: NATO, Russian influence, coal miners, and more
Article: By Katie Dahl This weekâ€™s highlight reel of TV News moments fact-checked by our partners at PolitiFact, FactCheck.org, and The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker feature the presidential tweet during the congressional hearing about Russian influence on the election, what Germany does and doesnâ€™t owe to NATO and the U.S., what a coal miner and single mom do and donâ€™t pay in taxes, whether GOP amendments were included in Obamacare, and a breakdown of the statistics weâ€™ve been hearing about the 9th Circuit. Claim: Germany owes money to NATO and the U.S. for defense (false) After a face-to-face meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel at the White House, President Donald Trump tweeted:Â â€œGermany owes vast sums of money to NATO & the United States must be paid more for the powerful, and very expensive, defense it provides to Germany!â€ The tweet was featured on â€œBBC World News Today.â€ PolitiFactâ€™s Allison Gravesâ€™ analysis was that â€œTrump is misunderstanding how NATOâ€™s joint defense is paid for, and that Germany doesnâ€™t owe anything.â€ SheÂ explained that â€œ[a]s of 2014, NATOâ€™s collective agreement directed members to spend 2 percent of their GDP on defense spending by 2024â€¦Â Trump likely was alluding to the fact Germany has not yet met the NATO target commitment for overall defense fundingâ€¦ Germany only pays 1.2 percent of their GDP on defense spending.â€ The misunderstanding was that â€œGermany doesnâ€™t pay that money to NATO or the United Statesâ€¦ [t]he United States decides what level of military spending it wants to have, as do all other NATO Â members.â€ Laicie Heeley, a military budget expert at the Stimson Center, a defense policy think tank, told Graves,Â â€œâ€˜Trump seems to represent the NATO alliance as a licensing deal â€” one in which countries like Germany pay the United States for its power and influenceâ€¦This is not the case.â€™â€  Claim: NSA, FBI said â€˜Russia did not influence electoral processâ€™ (false) During a House Intelligence Committee hearing on March 20, FBI Director James Comey and National Security Agency (NSA) Director Michael S. Rogers were asked questions about Russian influence in the U.S. presidential election. While the hearing was still going on, President Trump tweeted, â€œNSA and FBI tell Congress that Russia did not influence electoral process.â€ According to Eugene Kiely and Robert Farley of FactCheck.org, â€œthatâ€™s not what Comey or Rogers told the committee.â€ Lauren Carroll wrote for PolitiFact: â€œComey and Rogers said they believe Russia meddled in the race leading up to Election Day, chiefly by cyber-infiltrating the Democratic National Committee and other political organizations. Contrary to Trumpâ€™s tweet, they also said the intelligence community did not assess whether Russiaâ€™s actions actually had a measurable impact on the election outcome or public opinion.â€ The presidentâ€™s tweet itself became part of the hearing:Â â€œWhen later asked about the presidential tweet, Comey said it did not reflect what he and Rogers had said: â€˜It certainly wasnâ€™t our intention to say that today,â€™â€ reported Glenn Kessler from The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker.  Claim: Coal miners and single moms pay for public broadcasting (itâ€™s $.20 and $0) While talking about the presidentâ€™s proposed budget cuts, White House Budget Director Mick Mulvaney asked, â€œcan we really continue to ask a coal miner in West Virginia or a single mom in Detroit to pay for these programs? The answer was no. We can ask them to pay for defense, and we will, but we canâ€™t ask them to continue to pay for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.â€ By asking the question, he seemed to insinuate that coal miners and single moms pay for public broadcasting now. Kessler looked at the numbers using the H&R Block tax calculator and the Bureau of Labor Statistics and found that â€œsingle mothers in Detroit, most of whom are living in poverty, likely pay no taxes at all and instead would be receiving funds from the U.S. government via the Earned Income Tax Credit.â€ And in three examples of coal mining jobs, Kessler reported that a coal miner â€œowed no income taxes,â€ a loading machine operator â€œpaid about 20 cents of his taxes to the CPB,â€ and supervisors of production workers â€œpaid 60 cents.â€  Claim: Hundreds of Republican amendments were adopted in Obamacare (half true) During a conversation about political maneuvering and obstructionism related to the proposedÂ American Health Care Act, Rep. Luis Gutierrez, D., Ill., defended the actions of Democrats offering amendments and said â€œhundreds of Republican amendments were adopted in the ACA.â€ Reporting for PolitiFact, Gabrielle Healy foundÂ â€œ788 amendments were submitted during the ACAâ€™s markup in the Senate Committee for Health, Education, Labor and Pensions committee (HELP). Three quarters of them were filed by the committeeâ€™s Republican membersâ€¦ Of those, 161 were adopted in whole or revised form.â€ She also noted that many of the Republican amendments were â€œtechnical in nature.â€ An expert, â€œTimothy Jost, emeritus professor of law at Washington and Lee University School of Law,â€ told her that â€˜the basic statement that hundreds were adopted is wrong.â€™â€  Claim: less than 1/10 of 1 percent of 9th Circuit decisions are overturned by the Supreme Court (not very helpful) The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has been in the news recently because of itsÂ decision to halt the presidentâ€™s travel ban executive order. President Trump said in a news conference last month that â€œ80 percentâ€ of the courtâ€™sÂ decisions are overturned. Then more recently, Rep. John Conyers Jr., D., Mich., used a very different figure, saying â€œless than one-tenth of one percent of 9th Circuit decisions are overturned.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee reported â€œitâ€™s more complicated than thatâ€¦ Most cases reviewed by the Supreme Court get reversed, so the number or rate of reversals is not necessarily reflective of the courtâ€™s performance.â€ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker also reported that in: â€œthe 2014-2015 term, the 9th Circuitâ€™s reversal rate was about 60 percent, below the average rate of 72 percent. In the 2015-2016 term, the latest year of data available, the 9th Circuit courtâ€™s reversal rate was 80 percent, and the average rate was 67 percent. This is the figure that Trump cites. â€¦But the 80 percent figure represents a small fraction of the cases that the 9th Circuit hears in a given term â€” roughly one-tenth of 1 percent. This is the figure that Conyers cites.â€ In the end, Lee wrote, the statistics both Trump and Conyers used â€œ[do] not add much to the debate,â€ because they â€œlack context.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribeÂ here.

Title: KittenFeedâ€“ sometimes a suddenly popular site leverages the Wayback Machine
Article: From of the leader of the Wayback Machine project: Lucy (17 year old girl from SF) setup TrumpScratch.com Press reports suggest she received a cease and desist letter fromÂ the Trump organization in New York (update: now that letter is contested). She changed the site to KittenFeed.com At some point KittenFeed.com was re-directed to the Wayback Machine. It overwhelmed our servers so our engineers re-configured our cache to support the 5 meg MP3 on the page (the Rick Roll audio). KittenFeed.com appears now to have re-directed to facescratch.com, thereby not leveraging the Wayback Machine. We found it interesting to see the Wayback Machine, meant for historical research, used on a live site.

Title: TV news highlights with fact checks: proposed health care reform
Article: By Katie Dahl In this weekâ€™s roundup of fact-checked TV news from the TV NewsÂ Archive, our fact checking partnersâ€“FactCheck.org, PolitiFact, and The Washington Postâ€˜s Fact Checkerâ€“dug intoÂ statements from congressional leaders and the Trump administration about the proposed American Health Care Act. Claim: the Congressional Budget Office reported the American Health Care Act will decrease premiums (yes and no) AlthoughÂ one of the most popular headlines that came out of the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) report was that 24 million fewer Americans would have health insurance as a result of the American Health Care Act (AHCA), House Speaker Paul Ryan, R., Wis., chose toÂ emphasizeÂ another significant oneâ€“the prediction that the AHCA would lower premiums. PolitiFactâ€™s Tom Kertscher wrote, one, that this claim is specific to â€œthe roughly 7 percent of Americans who buy health insurance on their own because they arenâ€™t covered by an employer or a program such as Medicaid.â€ Two, â€œ[i]n 2018 and 2019, average premiums would be 15 percent to 20 percent higher than under Obamacareâ€¦ mainly because the penalties under Obamacare for not getting insurance would be eliminated, â€˜inducing fewer comparatively healthy people to sign up.â€™â€ But then, three, â€œ[p]remiums would start to drop in 2020. And by 2026, the premiums, on average, would be 10 percent lower than they would have been under Obamacare. Thatâ€™s expected for several reasons: The GOP legislation would provide grants to states that could be used to reduce premiums; the bill would eliminate a requirement for insurers to offer plans covering certain percentages of health care expenses; and a younger mix of enrollees.â€ Thatâ€™s one angle. Another is that although premiums may go down for some, like younger people, they will be â€œâ€˜20 percent to 25 percent higher for a 64-year-oldâ€™ by 2026, even though average premiums would be 10 percent lower compared with current law,â€ wrote Lori Robertson and Eugene Kiely at FactCheck.org. If you want information about the 24 million fewer people being uninsured claim, read more from Robertson and Kiely at FactCheck.org.   Claim:Â 1/3 of counties only have one health insurer left (true) President Donald Trump, while talking about current health insurance options for people looking for coverage through the exchanges, made this statement. â€œOne-third of the countiesâ€“think of it, one-thirdâ€”only have one insurer left.â€ According to Lauren Carroll of PolitiFact, this is true. â€œIn 32 percent of counties, individuals looking to buy health insurance through the Affordable Care Act online marketplace have just one choice for their insurance provider, according to an analysis by the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation, last updated in November 2016.â€ She went on to write â€œof the approximately 9.2 million people enrolled in the Affordable Care Act exchanges in 2017, about 1.9 million could only purchase insurance from one company.â€  Claim: Obamacare didnâ€™t have any hearings in the House (clearly wrong) White House Budget Director Mick Mulvaney hit the Sunday political talk show circuit this weekend to, among others, make this claim about the proposedÂ American Health Care Act. â€œWe already had two committee hearings, which I believe is two more than Obamacare had in the House.â€ Glenn Kessler, reporting forÂ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker,Â looked into the legislative history of Obamacare, or the Affordable Care Act, and found this. â€œWe have about 20 hearings, many aired on C-SPAN. Thatâ€™s 18 more than the current replacement billâ€¦. So Mulvaneyâ€™s comments are clearly wrong.â€ He admitted, though, that while the trip through the legislative process for the Affordable Care Act included hearings, it was also complex, and as one expert he interviewed put it, â€œthe â€˜ad hocâ€™ process that led to the ACA is â€˜an illustrative example of modern lawmaking, especially for major initiatives.â€™â€  Claim: Emergency room visits increased under the ACA (mostly true) Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price talked about a specific Obamacare goal to lower visits to the emergency room, where, PolitiFact noted, they â€œby law cannot turn patients away, [but] they can become a health care provider of last resort, even for more minor conditions that could be handled just as wellâ€“and more inexpensivelyâ€“in a doctorâ€™s office.â€ Price said that the Obama administrationÂ claimed â€œthey were going to be able to drive folks away from one of the most expensive areas for the provision of health care, and that is the emergency roomsâ€¦ In fact, they did just the opposite.â€ Louis Jacobson reported for PolitiFact that â€œPrice has a strong case.â€ He went on to write thatÂ while â€œthe data varies a bit from study to study, the findings generally fail to provide any evidence that emergency room use has decreased after the law [Affordable Care Act] took effect. Indeed, several studies found increases in emergency room use, though modestly. Price overstated the case slightly, but heâ€™s basically correct. We rate the statement Mostly True.â€  Claim: The number of people who werenâ€™t eligible for Medicaid coverage before the ACA, but have it now, is small (false) While Secretary Price got it right on emergency rooms, aÂ statement he made on Medicaid was rated â€œFalseâ€ by PolitiFactâ€™s Aaron Shockman. On â€œMeet the Pressâ€ last Sunday, Price said the â€œnumber of individuals who actually got coverage through the exchange who didnâ€™t have coverage before, or who werenâ€™t eligible for Medicaid before is relatively small. So weâ€™ve turned things upside down completely for 3 million, or 4 million, or 5 million individuals.â€ Shockmanâ€™s analysis is that Price â€œmade the case that the number of new people insured as a result of Obamacare can be overstated.â€ But, â€œ[n]onpartisan health care analysts at the Kaiser Family Foundation have concluded that, as of March 2016, more than 11 million Americans have gained access to health care as part of the Medicaid expansion. As we noted, an additional 3.2 million Americans signed up for Medicaid but were previously eligible.â€ The second pool of people Price referred to also seems problematic. â€œFinding data on the number of previously uninsured people who signed up for care through a health care exchange is more challenging. But the numbers that do exist further undercut Price,â€ reported Sharockman. â€œIn 2015, researchers at the nonpartisan RAND Corporation estimated that 4.1 million previously uninsured Americans had gained access through a health care exchange or marketplace. Thatâ€™s roughly 15 million Americans who werenâ€™t insured who now are, which is three to five times the number Price used.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: TV news highlights: wiretaps, Gitmo detainees, and more
Article: By Katie Dahl Our weekly TV News highlight reel features fact checks by reporters atÂ The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, PolitiFact, and FactCheck.org ofÂ President Donald Trump, his spokespeople, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, and Attorney General Jeff Sessions.  Claim: Obama wiretapped Trump Tower (unsupported) President Donald Trump took to Twitter this week with an allegation that President Barack Obama tapped his phones during the election. He wrote: â€œTerrible! Just found out that Obama had my â€˜wires tappedâ€™ in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!â€ FactCheck.orgâ€™s Eugene Kiely broke down Trumpâ€™s claims, the sources he used, and the White House press teamâ€™s response, writing â€œthere is no evidence that the FBI wiretapped Trumpâ€™s phone or his campaign offices in Trump Tower. Indeed, the director of national intelligence flatly denied it. [hyperlink added]â€ Glenn Kessler, reportingÂ for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker, wrote that the author of the Heat Street article, the â€œmost important oneâ€ of the articles the White House provided as evidence for the presidentâ€™s claims, now says she â€œnever reported there was wiretap and instead pointed the finger at Breitbart.â€ Sarah Huckabee Sanders, deputy press secretary for the White House, said â€œ[e]verybody acts like President Trump is the one that came up with this idea and just threw it out thereâ€¦ There are multiple news outlets that have reported this.â€ For PolitiFact, Allison Graves wrote that Huckabeeâ€™sÂ defense of the tweets is â€œFalse.â€ Lauren Carroll went further and concluded that â€œgiven recent comments from White House spokespeople, it appears more likely that Trump took several media reports about legitimate intelligence investigations into his associatesâ€™ possible Russia ties and wove them into a new, unsubstantiated theory that Obama himself did something illegal.â€  Claim: Clinton impeached for far less (two Pinocchios) House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D., Calif., drew a comparison between the circumstances of President Bill Clintonâ€™s impeachment and the disclosures about communications between Attorney General Sessions and the Russian ambassador. â€œI remind you that this Congress impeached a president for something so far less, having nothing to do with his duties as president of the United States,â€ she said. Michelle Ye Hee Lee ofÂ TheÂ Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker examined the two cases and observed: â€œIf one were to weigh Pelosiâ€™s claim based on whether Sessions and Clinton lied under oath, itâ€™s clear Clintonâ€™s case is not â€˜far lessâ€™ than Sessionsâ€™s. But the content of Clintonâ€™s lies (his sex life) was â€˜far lessâ€™ important than the content of Sessionsâ€™s statements (about potential foreign influence in U.S. elections).â€  Claim: Jeff Sessions lied to Congress (unclear) During Attorney General Jeff Sessionsâ€™ confirmation hearing in January, Sen. Al Franken, D., Minn., asked â€œwhat will you doâ€ if evidence surfaces to support a CNN report that â€œâ€˜[t]here was a continuing exchange of information during the campaign between Trumpâ€™s surrogates and intermediaries for the Russian government.â€™â€ In answering the question, Sessions said â€œIâ€™m not aware of any of those activities. I have been called a surrogate at a time or two in that campaign and I didnâ€™t have â€” did not have communications with the Russians.â€ Then March 1, The Washington Post reported that Jeff Sessions met with the Russian ambassador twice. In response to the now confirmed meetings, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi tweeted Sessions â€œlied under oathâ€ and called for his resignation. FactCheck.orgâ€™s Robert Farley reported, though, that â€œlegal experts say it would be difficult to prosecute a perjury charge against Sessions, given the ambiguity of the context of his statement.â€ In defending himself, Sessions said â€œI never had meetings with Russian operatives or Russian intermediaries about the Trump campaign,â€ which he argues was the focus of Frankenâ€™s question. Lauren Carroll for PolitiFact similarly reported, â€œ[I]tâ€™s not 100 percent clear that Sessions made an intentionally false statement, though he appears to have omitted relevant information.â€ One result is that the attorney general has recused himself from â€œany existing or future investigations of any matter relating in any way to the campaigns for president of the United States.â€ Louis Jacobson offered additional context in answering â€œfour questions about when senators meet with ambassadors.â€  Claim: People go to Planned Parenthood for mammograms (referrals mainly) Echoed in a  statementÂ in a press conference yesterday, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D., N.Y., Â claimed in a tweet that â€œ#Trumpcare cuts @PPFA funds, hurting millions of women who turn there for mammograms, maternity care, cancer screenings & more.â€ Michelle Ye Hee Lee wroteÂ that â€œ[m]ammograms have come to symbolize whether Planned Parenthood truly is a health-care organization, as supporters say, or mainly an abortion provider that masquerades as a reproductive health organization, as opponents say.â€ But, reportedÂ Lee, â€œPlanned ParenthoodÂ does referralsÂ for mammogramsâ€¦ It does not have mammogram machines at its affiliate clinics.â€  Claim: Obama released 122 Gitmo detainees now back on battlefield (mostly false) A former Guantanamo Bay detainee released under the Obama administration was killed in a U.S. military airstrike in Yemen this month. President Trump reacted on Twitter, writing, â€œ122 vicious prisoners, released by the Obama administration from Gitmo, have returned to the battlefield. Just another terrible decision!â€ But Robert Farley reportedÂ â€œitâ€™s only nine former detainees. The other 113 were released under President George W. Bush.â€ Lauren Carroll weighed in as well, writing â€œTrumpâ€™s claim that the Obama administration released 122 prisoners from Guantanamo that â€œreturned to the battlefieldâ€ is right on the numbers but wrong on who is to blame.â€  To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here. Â  Due to an editing error now fixed, we inadvertently referred to Rep. Alan Lowenthal, D., Calif., when we meant to refer to Sen. Chuck Schumer, D., N.Y., March 10, 2017.

Title: TV news highlights: overtime pay, Middle East, murder rate and more
Article: by Katie Dahl President Donald Trump addressed Congress for the first time this weekÂ and the Democratic National Committee elected a new chair, Thomas Perez. Here are five claims our fact-checking partners examined this week, paired with correspondingÂ clipsÂ from the Trump Archive and the TV News Archive. Claim: Trump wants to eliminate overtime pay for people (mostly false) In an interview on NBCâ€™s Meet the Press, newly elected Democratic National Committee Chair Thomas Perez said, â€œDonald Trump wants to eliminate overtime pay for people.â€ PolitiFactâ€™s Allison Graves hadnâ€™t heard that one before, so she looked into it and found that while Trump â€œhas not talked about eliminating overtime pay, he has supported rolling back an Obama-era regulation that would expand the number of people eligible for overtime.â€ Robert Farley from FactCheck.org confirmedÂ with the DNCâ€™s press office that â€œPerez was referring to the overtime rule proposed by President Barack Obama (while Perez was the labor secretary), and the possibility that Trump may squash it.â€ But Farley says â€œ[v]iewers of NBCâ€™s Meet the Press on Feb. 26 were left with the false impression from Perez that Trump wants to do away with federal overtime pay requirements altogether. And there is no evidence Trump wants to do that.â€  Claim: Murder rate increase fastest in nearly half century (basically correct) In his first address to Congress, President Trump claimed that the 2015 murder rate â€œexperienced its largest single-year increase in nearly half a century,â€ and that in â€œChicago, more than 4,000 people were shot last year alone.â€ Louis Jacobson and Amy Sherman found for PolitiFact that â€œFBI data shows a clear spike in homicides between 2014 and 2015â€“a 10.8 percent increase. This does rank as the biggest year-to-year jump in murders since 1970-71, when the number rose by 11.1 percent.â€ The Washington Post fact-checkers Glenn Kessler and Michelle Ye Hee Lee agreed, but wrote â€œoverall, violent crime is on a decades-long declineâ€¦ This is why criminologists do not make generalizations about crime trends based on short-term comparisons of rates, such as annual or monthly changes.â€ FactCheck.orgâ€™s Farley reported similar data, saying the murder rate â€œdid go up by 10.8 percent from 2014 to 2015, the long-term trend has been a decrease in murders. The 2015 rate, 4.9 per 100,000 people, is less than half the peak rate of 10.2 in 1980, according to FBI data.â€ Trumpâ€™s Chicago statistics are also correct, say Jacobson and Sherman. AccordingÂ â€œto data released by the Chicago Police Department shortly after the close of 2016, the city had 762 murders, 3,550 shooting incidents, and 4,331 shooting victims in 2016.â€  Claim: NATO partners arenâ€™t meeting their financial obligations (true) Continuing a familiar campaign talking point, President Trump said that our NATO partners â€œmust meet their financial obligations,â€ and went on to claim that because of his â€œvery strong and frank discussionsâ€¦ the money is pouring in.â€ Jacobson and Sherman found that yes â€œonly a handful of NATOâ€™s 28 members have fulfilled the pledge to spend at least 2 percent of their economy on defense â€” Great Britain, the United States, Greece and Estonia.â€ Kessler and Lee, though, wroteÂ that the comment about the money pouring in is a â€œbit nonsensical,â€ presumably because â€œthe money would not be going to the United States or even necessarily to NATO; this is money that countries would spend to bolster their own military forces.â€  Claim: Defense budget one of the biggest increases in history (mostly false) In touting his budget proposal, President Trump saidÂ it â€œcalls for one of the largest increases in national defense spending in American history.â€ Sherman and Jacobson looked at just the last 30 years and found â€œthere have been 10 years when the base defense budget has gone up by more than what Trump has requested. In some years, the increase was more than double Trumpâ€™s.â€ The defense analysts they talked with â€œconfirmed that while the proposal is a significant increase, it is not remarkable.â€ They rated the statement Mostly False.  Claim: Weâ€™ve spent $6 trillion dollars in the Middle East (not correct) President Trump told Congress that â€œAmerica has spent approximately $6 trillion dollars in the Middle East,â€ but fact-checkers indicate heâ€™s off by some trillions. Robert Farley reportedÂ the number is $1.7 trillion: â€œIn a report released this month, the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service said that the Department of Defense estimates that the U.S. has spent $1.7 trillion on â€˜war-related activitiesâ€™ from 2001 through Sept. 30, 2016. That includes military operations in Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Libya.â€ The PolitiFact reporters wroteÂ â€œhe is confusing money thatâ€™s been spent with money that researchers say will be spent,â€ and The Washington Postâ€™s agreed, writingÂ the â€œ$6 trillion figure adds in estimates of future spending, such as interest on the debt and veterans care for the next three decades.â€  Read here about tips to useÂ  the Trump Archive. To receive the TV News Archiveâ€™s email newsletter, subscribe here.

Title: How to Use the Trump Archive to find TV news appearances, fact checks, and share clips
Article: by Katie Dahl The experimentalÂ Trump Archive, which we launched in January, is a collection of President Donald Trumpâ€™s appearancesÂ on TV news shows, including interviews, speeches, and press conferences dating back to 2009. Now largely hand-curated, theÂ Trump Archive is a prototype of the typeÂ of collection on a public figure or topic possible toÂ make with material from our library of TV news. We are starting to reach out to machine learning collaborators to develop tools to make it more efficient to create such collections, and we have plans to publish similar collections on the Congressional leadership on both sides of the party aisle. The growing Trump Archive contains a lot of contentâ€“928 clips and countingâ€“so weâ€™ve put together some pointers and ideas for how to use the collection.Â  Anna Wiener at The New Yorker used the Trump Archive for â€œimmersion therapy: a means of overcoming shock through prolonged exposure,â€ while the The Wall Street Journalâ€™s Geoffrey A. Fowler proposedÂ the Trump Archive could be used to hold politicians accountable by people doing own fact-checking: â€œAt a time when facts are considered up for debate, thereâ€™s more value than ever in being able to check the tape yourself.â€ Fact-checking in the Trump Archive The Trump Archive is a great place to spend time if youâ€™re hungry for aggregated fact-checking and added context around President Trumpâ€™s statements. We incorporateÂ fact checks from our partners at FactCheck.org, PolitiFact, and The Washington Postâ€™s Fact CheckerÂ in a variety of ways. From this page you can explore TV programs that include at least one fact-checked Trump statement. After choosing a program, look for the fact-checked icon Â Â on the program timeline. When you click on that icon, youâ€™ll be able to watch the video of the statement and then click through to a fact-checking article by one of our partners.  And if youâ€™re eager to look for a specific topic, such as â€œterrorism,â€ or â€œimmigration,â€Â this table is a great place to start. You can search for a topic using the trusty find functionÂ on your computer, or download the table and view the list as a spreadsheet. Find a list of topics at PolitiFact and FactCheck.org.  Search the Trump Archive The search function, on the left side of the screen on the front page of the Trump Archive, allows you to find words or phrases within the closed captioning for a particular clip.Â Since those transcribers are working in real-time and at lightening speed, the captionsÂ donâ€™t produce a perfect transcript, but they will get you really close to where you need to be.  For example, I searched for â€œbelieve meâ€ in the Trump Archive and came up with hundreds of results. While that particular example may only be useful for artists and linguists, the functionality can be applied in many ways. For example, there are almost 200 results for a search of â€œIran Deal,â€ 70+ results for â€œradical Islamic terrorists,â€ and when you search â€œjobs,â€ the results almost match the number in our total collection, revealing how often Donald Trump talks about jobs.  When we heard the President would be taking action to remove an expansion of rights for the transgender community, we looked for what he may have said about it before by searching â€œtransgenderâ€ in the caption search. It yielded six programs in which he spoke publicly about it.  Because of the imperfect nature of closed captioning transcripts, your search is often more successful if you donâ€™t try for an exact quote. For example, you may know TrumpÂ said something like â€œwe can make the kind of change together that you dream of.â€ The closed captioning quote may actually be â€œan make the find a change together that you beam of.â€ But in those circumstances where you need to search for an exact quote, try using this, ~0. For example, â€œthe lion, the witch, and the wardrobeâ€~0 Â . The ~0 tells the search box to look for all these words without any other words in between them, thus next to each other.  Browse the Trump Archive by TV show If you know the program name of the Trump statement youâ€™re looking for, you can use the â€œTopics & Subjectsâ€ filter on the left side navigation. So for instance, you may recall that Trump said something you want to find on an episode of 60 Minutes. Find Topics & Subjects on the left side of the page and click on â€œMore.â€  Then check the boxes of the relevant program(s), in this case, 60 Minutes. Hit â€œapply your filters,â€ and then browse all the 60 Minutes programs in the Trump Archive.   Make your own shareable TV clips Once you find that video clip where Trump says something you want to share, you can make your own video clip of up to three minutes that can be easily embedded into a post. If you post the link on twitter, the clip appears within the body of the tweet and can be played without clicking through to the TV News Archive. To start, click on the icon to â€œShare, embed or refine this clip!â€Â   A window will then open up to present (highlighted in orange) the closed captioning of the 60-second pre-defined segmentâ€”and the captioning of the 60 seconds before and after (not highlighted) for context. Important: the captions come from real-time closed captioning, which means they are often incomplete, garbled and not precisely aligned. This is all still an experiment, remember. Be sure to watch your clip before you post to make sure you captured what you meant to.  â€œGrabâ€ the quote marks at the beginning and end of the highlighted segment and through a bit of trial and error, find the right in and out points for the clip. Note that each time the quote marks move, the player starts to play and the URL changes to update the â€œstartâ€ and â€œendâ€ points of the clip â€” named to reflect the number of seconds into the entire program. Remember: Watch your clip before you post.  Pro tip: If you clip a quote thatâ€™s fewer than 10 seconds it might not play, so give it a bit of time to run. Copy the URL and paste it elsewhere. Click one of the variety of share method icons on the bottom of the edit window (Twitter, Facebook, etc.) The embed icon </> will offer two flavors of embed codes for the portion you have selectedâ€”one for an iFrame, the other for many WordPress sites.  Fun, right? Now go share another. Let us know if you have any questions by emailing us at politicalad@archive.org; and please, do share what uses you find for the Trump Archive.

Title: TV news highlights with fact checks
Article: By Nancy Watzman and Katie Dahl Last week, our national fact checking partners concentrated on two events featuring President Donald Trump: a press conference on February 16, and his rally in Melbourne, Florida on February 18. The Conservative Political Action Conference is being hosted this week. Look outÂ for fact-checking of President Trumpâ€™s speech soon. Â Here are some highlights, along with TV news segments from the Trump Archive and TV News Archive. Steve Bannon and Reince Priebus addressed the conference yesterday. Bannon again called the press the â€œopposition party.â€   Claim: Obama released Gitmo detainee that recently became a suicide bomber (wasnâ€™t him) Deputy assistant to the president, Sebastian Gorka, on Fox & Friends: â€œSo President Obama released lots and lots of people that were there for a very good reason, and what happened? Almost half the time, they returned to the battlefield. This individualâ€¦ goes and executes a suicide attack in Iraq.â€ At FactCheck.org, Farley wrote â€œGorka wrongly suggested the man was released by President Barack Obama. He was transferredâ€¦ President George W. Bushâ€¦ then wrongly claimed that among detainees released by Obama, â€˜almost half the time, they returned to the battlefield.â€™ According to the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, about 12.4 percent of those transferred from Gitmo under Obama are either confirmed or suspected of reengaging.â€  Claim: there are 13, 14, 15 million undocumented people in the country (too high) At a press briefing this week, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer said â€œ12, 14, 15 million people [are] in the country illegally,â€ but Yee gave him Three Pinocchios for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker. â€œSpicerâ€™s statement that there are about 12 million people in the country illegally is safely within the margin of error in credible demographics research. But once he enters the realm of â€˜13, 14, 15 millionâ€™ or â€˜potentially more,â€™ his claim becomes problematic.â€  Claim: Thomas Jefferson said â€œnothing can be believed which is seen in a newspaper.â€ (out of context) At his rally in Florida, Trump said President Thomas Jefferson had said that â€œnothing can be believed which is seen in a newspaper. Truth itselfâ€¦.becomes suspicious by being put into that polluted vehicle.â€ However, â€œTrump selectively quotes from Jefferson here, who, for most of his life, was a fierce defender of the need for a free press,â€ Kessler wrote for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker. PolitiFact staff made a similar point, using this quote as evidence: â€œAnd were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers, or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter.â€   Claim: something happened in Sweden. (Not exactly) By far the quote that received the most attention from the presidentâ€™s rally were his comments about Sweden: â€œWeâ€™ve got to keep our country safe â€¦ You look at whatâ€™s happening last night in Swedenâ€¦ Sweden? Who would believe this? Sweden. They took in large numbers. Theyâ€™re having problems like they never thought possible.â€ â€œThis was a very strange comment. Nothing had happened the night before in Sweden,â€ wrote Kessler for The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker. Â A White House spokesperson said later that he â€œwas talking about rising crime and recent incidents in general and not referring to a specific incident.â€  PolitiFact reporter Miriam Valverde reported on the Fox news interview on Swedish crime rates, which aired the night before the rally and purportedly inspired Trumpâ€™s comments. Valverde quoted several Swedish experts countering the argument that crime rates are rising in Sweden, including political scientist Henrik Selin, who said that â€œ[i]n general, crime statistics have gone down the last (few) years, and no there is no evidence to suggest that new waves of immigration has lead to increased crime.â€ Robert Farley reported for Â FactCheck.org, â€œSwedish authorities and criminologists say President Donald Trump is exaggerating crime in Sweden as a result of its liberal policy of accepting refugees from Syria and other Middle Eastern countries.â€  Claim:Â The stock market has hit record numbers (mostly true) The President mentioned theÂ economy at aÂ press conference, saying â€œThe stock market has hit record numbers, as you know. And there has been a tremendous surge of optimism in the business world.â€ At PolitiFact,Â Miriam Valverde rated this as â€œMostly True,â€ reporting â€œAll three major stock indexes closed at record highs for five days in row on Feb. 15.â€  Claim: the media is less trustworthy than Congress (mostly false, butâ€¦) Also at theÂ press conference, President Trump excoriated the media, saying journalists â€œwill not tell you the truth and treat the wonderful people of our country with the respect that they deserve,â€ that the â€œpress is out of control,â€ and that the media has a â€œlower approval rate than Congress, I think thatâ€™s right, I donâ€™t know.â€ PolitiFact reporter Jon Greenberg rated the trust claim as â€œmostly falseâ€: â€œCongress actually ranks below the news media, according to surveys from three different research groups spanning several years. In two polls, mistrust in the media broke 40 percent, which is hardly anything to brag about. But in those studies, mistrust in Congress was over 50 percent.â€  Glenn Kessler and Michelle Ye Hee Lee at The Washington Postâ€™s Fact Checker agreed that Congress ranks lower than the mediaâ€“but that that isnâ€™t saying much: â€œ[B]esides Congress, only â€˜big businessâ€™ ranks lower than the media â€” but itâ€™s enough to make Trumpâ€™s claim incorrect.â€ FactCheck.org chimed in, noting that the â€œpublicâ€™s approval of Congress is lower than its trust in the media,â€ but pointed out thereâ€™s more public trust in Trump than in the media: â€œTrump would have been correct to say that trust in the media is even lower than approval of himself. According to Gallup, Trumpâ€™s approval rating stood at 41 percent, as of the week ending Feb. 12, while the publicâ€™s trust in the media was down to 32 percent.â€ Â   Claim: Trump had biggest electoral college win since Ronald Reagan. (False) President Trump claimed his victory marked â€œthe biggest electoral college win since Ronald Reagan.â€ NBC reporter Peter Alexander challenged him on the spot, saying, â€œWhy should Americans trust you when you have accused information they have received as being fake when you have been providing information that is fake?â€ Trump didnâ€™t answer the question, but rather pivoted by asking whether the reporter agreed that his victory was substantial. Â  According to our fact-checking partners, there have been three presidents since Reagan who received more electoral college votes than Trump. FactCheck.org noted â€œTrumpâ€™s Electoral College victory margin ranks 46th out of 58 presidential elections.â€ Kessler and Lee wrote: â€œOf the nine presidential elections since 1984, Trumpâ€™s electoral college win ranks seventh.â€  Claim: Hillary Clinton gave away 20 percent of the uranium in the United States (false) President Trump asserted a claim the Washington Post Fact Checker has given Four Pinocchios, that Hillary Clinton â€œgave away 20 percent of the uranium in the United States,â€ going on to say, â€œyou know what uranium is, right? This thing called nuclear weapons and other things like lots of things are done with uranium, including some bad things.â€ insinuate that the uranium could be used in a Russian nuclear weapon. FactCheck.org wrote: â€œThe deal Clinton had a role in approving gave Russia ownership of 20 percent of U.S. production capacity â€” not existing stocks of uranium. Furthermore, Clinton alone could not have stopped the deal; only the president could have done that with a finding that national security would be endangered. Lastly, none of the uranium goes to Russia. That would require export licenses.â€

Title: The Internet Archive Pushes Back on â€œNotice and Staydownâ€ in Recent Comments to the Copyright Office
Article: The US Copyright Office sought comments in its ongoing study of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) Section 512 safe harbor study. They are generally looking to find out how well the notice and takedown system is working for everyoneâ€”Internet platforms and users, as well as creators and copyright holders. We think the 1998 statute struck the right balance and is generally working well, a view shared by nearly all Internet platforms and users. However, some incumbent rightsholders and their advocacy organizations disagree and think the system needs to be completely redone because it is too hard to police copyright infringement online. These complaints fail to account for the exceeding high statutory damages rightsholders can claim and other mechanisms in copyright law that favor certain categories of rightsholders over new media creators and consumers. One dangerous idea that rightsholders continue to push for is a â€œnotice and staydownâ€ system. This sounds like a minor edit to notice and takedown, but in reality it would amount to mandatory filtering of the Internet for the purpose of policing copyright. Last summer we noted many of the general reasons why this idea is both dangerous and impractical. In our most recent comments, we focus more specifically on the direct threat such a system would pose to the Internet Archive and our various projects such as the Wayback Machine and the TV News Archive: For one thing, the Internet Archive preserves the state of any given web page as it existed on a particular date via the Wayback Machine. Being forced to automatically remove material from the Wayback Machine would irreparably harm the historical record. This would be harmful for journalists who use the Wayback Machine to report on important stories of which there would be no evidence without the Archive. It would be harmful for attorneys and litigants who regularly use the Wayback Machine as evidence in legal proceedings. The very knowledge that a filter was running on the Wayback Machine would undermine its credibility as an accurate snapshot of the Internet at a given point in time. Therefore, filtering is a direct threat to our mission. The Internet Archive also hosts the Political TV Ad Archive and the TV News Archive. As with the Wayback Machine, the very point of these archives is to preserve the historical record and ensure that politicians can be held accountable for their statements in ads or in TV appearances. A mandatory filter run on the TV News Archive might catch a famous song used in a political ad or at a campaign rally, and determine that such material must be removed. However, this would distort the historical record.
